[Many]3881-many also have perished , have erred , and sinned , for [women]3879-women .... O [[ye]3877-yea men]3883-ye men , how can it be but [women]3879-women should be strong , seeing [they]3879-women do thus ? "[162-esdras] - [ESDRAS]162-esdras . [I]0-i [The schoolmaster]409-the schoolmaster was leaving [the village]410-the village , and [everybody]411-everybody seemed sorry . [The miller at [Cresscombe]6-cresscombe]412-the miller at cresscombe lent [him]409-the schoolmaster [the small white tilted cart]413-the small white tilted cart and horse to carry [his]409-the schoolmaster goods to [the city]414-the city of [[his]409-the schoolmaster destination]415-his destination , about twenty miles off , such [a vehicle]416-a vehicle proving of quite sufficient size for [[the departing teacher]417-the departing teacher 's effects]418-the departing teacher 's effects . For [the schoolhouse]419-the schoolhouse had been partly furnished by [the managers]420-the managers , and the only cumbersome article possessed by [the master]421-the master , in addition to the packing - case of books , was a cottage piano that [he]421-the master had bought at an auction during the year in which [he]421-the master thought of learning instrumental music . But the enthusiasm having waned [he]421-the master had never acquired any skill in playing , and the purchased article had been a perpetual trouble to [him]421-the master ever since in [moving house]422-moving house . [The rector]423-the rector had gone away for the day , being [a man who disliked the sight of changes]424-a man who disliked the sight of changes . [He]423-the rector did not mean to return till the evening , when [the new school - teacher]425-the new school - teacher would have arrived and settled in , and everything would be smooth again . [The blacksmith]426-the blacksmith , [the farm bailiff]427-the farm bailiff , and [the schoolmaster]409-the schoolmaster [himself]409-the schoolmaster were standing in perplexed attitudes in the parlour before the instrument . [The master]421-the master had remarked that even if [he]421-the master got it into the cart [he]421-the master should not know what to do with it on [his]421-the master arrival at [Christminster]180-jude , [[the city]414-the city [he]421-the master was bound for , since [he]421-the master was only going into [temporary lodgings]432-temporary lodgings just at first]431-the city he was bound for , since he was only going into temporary lodgings just at first . [A little boy of eleven , who had been thoughtfully assisting in the packing]433-a little boy of eleven , who had been thoughtfully assisting in the packing , joined [the group of men]434-the group of men , and as [they]434-the group of men rubbed [their]434-the group of men chins [he]433-a little boy of eleven , who had been thoughtfully assisting in the packing spoke up , blushing at the sound of [his]433-a little boy of eleven , who had been thoughtfully assisting in the packing own voice : " [Aunt]3885-aunt have got [a great fuel - house]3886-a great fuel - house , and it could be put [there]3887-there , perhaps , till [you]163-phillotson 've found a place to settle in , [sir]3888-sir . "[433-a little boy of eleven , who had been thoughtfully assisting in the packing] " A proper good notion , "[426-the blacksmith] said [the blacksmith]426-the blacksmith . It was decided that [a deputation]436-a deputation should wait on [[the boy]437-the boy 's aunt]438-the boy 's aunt - [an old maiden resident]439-an old maiden resident - and ask [her]438-the boy 's aunt if [she]438-the boy 's aunt would house the piano till [Mr. Phillotson]163-phillotson should send for it . [The smith]440-the smith and [the bailiff]441-the bailiff started to see about the practicability of the suggested shelter , and [the boy]437-the boy and [the schoolmaster]409-the schoolmaster were left standing alone . " Sorry [I]444-the latter am going , [Jude]164-jude ? "[444-the latter] asked [the latter]444-the latter kindly . Tears rose into [the boy]437-the boy 's eyes , for [he]437-the boy was not among [the regular day scholars]446-the regular day scholars , who came unromantically close to [the schoolmaster]409-the schoolmaster 's life , but [one who had attended the night school only during [the present teacher]449-the present teacher 's term of office]448-one who had attended the night school only during the present teacher 's term of office . [The regular scholars]450-the regular scholars , if the truth must be told , stood at the present moment afar off , like [certain historic disciples]451-certain historic disciples , indisposed to any enthusiastic volunteering of aid . [The boy]437-the boy awkwardly opened the book [he]437-the boy held in [his]437-the boy hand , which [Mr. Phillotson]163-phillotson had bestowed on [him]437-the boy as a parting gift , and admitted that [he]437-the boy was sorry . [My]440-the smith scheme , or dream , is to be [a university graduate]3894-a university graduate , and then to be ordained . By going to live at [Christminster]180-jude , or near [it]180-jude , [I]440-the smith shall be at headquarters , so to speak , and if [my]440-the smith scheme is practicable at all , [I]440-the smith consider that being on the spot will afford [me]440-the smith a better chance of carrying it out than [I]440-the smith should have elsewhere . [[Old Miss Fawley]165-old miss fawley 's fuel - house]456-old miss fawley 's fuel - house was dry , and eminently practicable ; and [she]165-old miss fawley seemed willing to give the instrument standing - room [there]3887-there . "[163-phillotson] [The cart]462-the cart creaked across [the green]464-the green , and disappeared round the corner by [the rectory - house]465-the rectory - house . [The boy]437-the boy returned to the draw - well at [the edge of [the greensward]468-the greensward]467-the edge of the greensward , where [he]437-the boy had left [his]437-the boy buckets when [he]437-the boy went to help [[his]437-the boy patron]469-his patron and [teacher]470-teacher in the loading . There was a quiver in [his]437-the boy lip now and after opening the well - cover to begin lowering the bucket [he]437-the boy paused and leant with [his]437-the boy forehead and arms against the framework , [his]437-the boy face wearing the fixity of [a thoughtful child 's who has felt the pricks of life]471-a thoughtful child 's who has felt the pricks of life somewhat before [his]437-the boy time . The well into which [he]437-the boy was looking was as ancient as [the village]410-the village itself , and from [his]437-the boy present position appeared as a long circular perspective ending in a shining disk of quivering water at a distance of a hundred feet down . There was a lining of green moss near the top , and nearer still the hart's - tongue fern . [He]437-the boy said to [himself]437-the boy , in the melodramatic tones of [a whimsical boy]473-a whimsical boy , that [the schoolmaster]409-the schoolmaster had drawn at that well scores of times on a morning like this , and would never draw there any more . " [I]437-the boy 've seen [him]437-the boy look down into it , when [he]437-the boy was tired with [his]437-the boy drawing , just as [I]437-the boy do now , and when [he]437-the boy rested a bit before carrying the buckets [home]3897-home ! But [he]437-the boy was too clever to bide [here]3898-here any longer - [a small sleepy place like this]3899-a small sleepy place like this ! "[437-the boy] A tear rolled from [his]437-the boy eye into the depths of the well . The morning was a little foggy , and [the boy]437-the boy 's breathing unfurled itself as a thicker fog upon the still and heavy air . [His]437-the boy thoughts were interrupted by a sudden outcry : " Bring on that water , will [ye]437-the boy , [[you]437-the boy idle young harlican]3900-you idle young harlican ! [It]485-it was as old - fashioned as [it]485-it was small , and [it]485-it rested in the lap of [an undulating upland adjoining [the North Wessex downs]487-the north wessex downs]486-an undulating upland adjoining the north wessex downs . Old as [it]485-it was , however , [the well - shaft]488-the well - shaft was probably the only relic of the local history that remained absolutely unchanged . [Many of [the thatched and dormered dwelling - houses]490-the thatched and dormered dwelling - houses]489-many of the thatched and dormered dwelling - houses had been pulled down of late years , and many trees felled on [the green]464-the green . Above all , [the original church]492-the original church , hump - backed , wood - turreted , and quaintly hipped , had been taken down , and either cracked up into heaps of road - metal in [the lane]493-the lane , or utilized as pig - sty walls , garden seats , guard - stones to fences , and rockeries in [the flower - beds of [the neighbourhood]495-the neighbourhood]494-the flower - beds of the neighbourhood . In place of [it]492-the original church [a tall new building of modern Gothic design , unfamiliar to English eyes]496-a tall new building of modern gothic design , unfamiliar to english eyes , had been erected on a new piece of ground by [a certain obliterator of historic records who had run down from [London]7-london and back in a day]497-a certain obliterator of historic records who had run down from london and back in a day . II Slender as was [Jude Fawley]180-jude 's frame [he]180-jude bore the two brimming house - buckets of water to [the cottage]501-the cottage without resting . Ah , that [a little maid]3927-a little maid should know such changes ! "[167-drusilla fawley] [Jude]180-jude , finding the general attention again centering on [himself]180-jude , went out to [the bakehouse]520-the bakehouse , where [he]180-jude ate the cake provided for [his]180-jude breakfast . The end of [his]180-jude spare time had now arrived , and emerging from [the garden]521-the garden by getting over the hedge at the back [he]180-jude pursued a path northward , till [he]180-jude came to a wide and lonely depression in [the general level of [the upland]523-the upland]522-the general level of the upland , which was sown as [a corn - field]524-a corn - field . [This vast concave]525-this vast concave was the scene of [his]180-jude labours for [Mr Troutham]176-mr troutham [the farmer]526-the farmer , and [he]180-jude descended into [the midst of [it]525-this vast concave]527-the midst of it . [The brown surface of [the field]529-the field]528-the brown surface of the field went right up towards the sky all round , where it was lost by degrees in the mist that shut out the actual verge and accentuated the solitude . The only marks on the uniformity of the scene were a rick of last year 's produce standing in the midst of [the arable]530-the arable , the rooks that rose at [his]180-jude approach , and the path athwart the fallow by which [he]180-jude had come , trodden now by [he]180-jude hardly knew whom , though once by [many of [[his]180-jude own dead family]532-his own dead family]531-many of his own dead family . " How ugly it is here ! "[180-jude] [he]180-jude murmured . The fresh harrow - lines seemed to stretch like the channellings in [a piece of new corduroy]533-a piece of new corduroy , lending a meanly utilitarian air to [the expanse]534-the expanse , taking away its gradations , and depriving it of all history beyond that of the few recent months , though to every clod and stone there really attached associations enough and to spare - echoes of songs from ancient harvest - days , of spoken words , and of sturdy deeds . Every inch of ground had been the site , first or last , of energy , gaiety , horse - play , bickerings , weariness . Groups of [gleaners]535-gleaners had squatted in the sun on [every square yard]536-every square yard . Love - matches that had populated [the adjoining hamlet]537-the adjoining hamlet had been made up there between reaping and carrying . Under the hedge which divided [the field]529-the field from [a distant plantation]539-a distant plantation [girls]540-girls had given [themselves]540-girls to [lovers who would not turn [their]541-lovers who would not turn their heads to look at them by the next harvest heads to look at [them]540-girls by the next harvest]541-lovers who would not turn their heads to look at them by the next harvest ; and in [that ancient cornfield]542-that ancient cornfield many [a man]543-a man had made love - promises to [a woman at whose voice [he]543-a man had trembled by the next seed - time after fulfilling [them]540-girls in [the church adjoining]545-the church adjoining]544-a woman at whose voice he had trembled by the next seed - time after fulfilling them in the church adjoining . But this neither [Jude]180-jude nor [the rooks around [him]180-jude]546-the rooks around him considered . For [them]547-them it was [a lonely place]548-a lonely place , possessing , in the one view , only the quality of [a work - ground]549-a work - ground , and in the other that of a granary good to feed in . [The boy]437-the boy stood under the rick before mentioned , and every few seconds used [his]437-the boy clacker or rattle briskly . At each clack [the rooks]551-the rooks left off pecking , and rose and went away on [their]551-the rooks leisurely wings , burnished like tassets of mail , afterwards wheeling back and regarding [him]437-the boy warily , and descending to feed at a more respectful distance . [He]180-jude sounded the clacker till [his]180-jude arm ached , and at length [his]180-jude heart grew sympathetic with the birds ' thwarted desires . [They]551-the rooks seemed , like [himself]180-jude , to be living in a world which did not want [them]551-the rooks . Why should [he]180-jude frighten [them]551-the rooks away ? [They]551-the rooks took upon more and more the aspect of [gentle friends]552-gentle friends and [pensioners]553-pensioners - [the only friends [he]180-jude could claim as being in the least degree interested in [him]180-jude , for [[his]180-jude aunt]555-his aunt]554-the only friends he could claim as being in the least degree interested in him , for his aunt had often told [him]180-jude that [she]555-his aunt was not . [He]180-jude ceased [his]180-jude rattling , and [they]551-the rooks alighted anew . " [Poor little dears]3928-poor little dears ! "[180-jude] said [Jude]180-jude , aloud . " [You]3928-poor little dears SHALL have some dinner - [you]3928-poor little dears shall . There is enough for [[us]551-the rooks all]3929-us all . [Farmer Troutham]173-farmer troutham can afford to let [you]3928-poor little dears have some . Eat , then [my]180-jude dear little birdies , and make a good meal ! "[180-jude] [They]551-the rooks stayed and ate , inky spots on [the nut - brown soil]556-the nut - brown soil , and [Jude]180-jude enjoyed [their]551-the rooks appetite . A magic thread of fellow - feeling united [his]180-jude own life with [theirs]551-the rooks . Puny and sorry as those lives were , they much resembled [his]180-jude own . [His]180-jude clacker [he]180-jude had by this time thrown away from [him]180-jude , as being a mean and sordid instrument , offensive both to the birds and to [himself]180-jude as [[their]551-the rooks friend]557-their friend . All at once [he]180-jude became conscious of a smart blow upon [his]180-jude buttocks , followed by a loud clack , which announced to [his]180-jude surprised senses that the clacker had been the instrument of offence used . [The birds]558-the birds and [Jude]180-jude started up simultaneously , and the dazed eyes of [the latter]444-the latter beheld [the farmer]526-the farmer in person , [the great Troutham]561-the great troutham [himself]561-the great troutham , [his]561-the great troutham red face glaring down upon [Jude]180-jude 's cowering frame , the clacker swinging in [his]180-jude hand . " So it 's ' Eat [my]561-the great troutham dear birdies , ' is it , [young man]3930-young man ? ' Eat , [dear birdies]3931-dear birdies , ' indeed ! And [you]3931-dear birdies 've been idling at [the schoolmaster]409-the schoolmaster 's too , instead of coming here , ha'n't [ye]3931-dear birdies , hey ? That 's how [you]3931-dear birdies earn [your]3931-dear birdies sixpence a day for keeping the rooks off [my]561-the great troutham corn ! "[561-the great troutham] Whilst saluting [Jude]180-jude 's ears with this impassioned rhetoric , [Troutham]173-farmer troutham had seized [his]173-farmer troutham left hand with [his]173-farmer troutham own left , and swinging [his]173-farmer troutham slim frame round [him]173-farmer troutham at arm's - length , again struck [Jude]180-jude on the hind parts with the flat side of [Jude]180-jude 's own rattle , till [the field]529-the field echoed with the blows , which were delivered once or twice at each revolution . " Do n't ' ee , [sir]3888-sir - please do n't ' ee ! "[563-the whirling child] cried [the whirling child]563-the whirling child , as helpless under the centrifugal tendency of [his]563-the whirling child person as a hooked fish swinging to land , and beholding [the hill]564-the hill , [the rick]565-the rick , [the plantation]566-the plantation , [the path]567-the path , and the rooks going round and round [him]563-the whirling child in an amazing circular race . " [I]563-the whirling child - [I]563-the whirling child sir - only meant that - there was a good crop in the ground - [I]563-the whirling child saw ['em]3935-'em sow it - and [the rooks]551-the rooks could have a little bit for dinner - and [you]3888-sir would n't miss it , [sir]3888-sir - and [Mr. Phillotson]163-phillotson said [I]563-the whirling child was to be kind to 'em - oh , oh , oh ! "[563-the whirling child] This truthful explanation seemed to exasperate [the farmer]526-the farmer even more than if [Jude]180-jude had stoutly denied saying anything at all , and [he]180-jude still smacked the whirling urchin , the clacks of the instrument continuing to resound all across [the field]529-the field and as far as the ears of [distant workers]570-distant workers - who gathered thereupon that [Jude]180-jude was pursuing [his]180-jude business of clacking with great assiduity - and echoing from [the brand - new church tower]571-the brand - new church tower just behind [the mist]572-the mist , towards [the building of which structure [the farmer]526-the farmer had largely subscribed , to testify [his]180-jude love for [God]177-god and [man]575-man]573-the building of which structure the farmer had largely subscribed , to testify his love for god and man . Presently [Troutham]173-farmer troutham grew tired of [his]173-farmer troutham punitive task , and depositing [the quivering boy]576-the quivering boy on [his]173-farmer troutham legs , took a sixpence from [his]173-farmer troutham pocket and gave it [him]576-the quivering boy in payment for [his]173-farmer troutham day 's work , telling [him]576-the quivering boy to go [home]3897-home and never let [him]576-the quivering boy see [him]576-the quivering boy in one of [those fields]578-those fields again . [Jude]180-jude leaped out of arm 's reach , and walked along [the trackway]579-the trackway weeping - not from the pain , though that was keen enough ; not from the perception of the flaw in the terrestrial scheme , by which what was good for [God]177-god 's birds was bad for [[God]177-god 's gardener]580-god 's gardener ; but with the awful sense that [he]180-jude had wholly disgraced [himself]180-jude before [he]180-jude had been a year in [the parish]581-the parish , and hence might be a burden to [[his]180-jude great - aunt]505-his great - aunt for life . With this shadow on [his]180-jude mind [he]180-jude did not care to show [himself]180-jude in [the village]410-the village , and went homeward by [a roundabout track behind a high hedge]584-a roundabout track behind a high hedge and across [a pasture]585-a pasture . Here [he]180-jude beheld scores of coupled earthworms lying half their length on the surface of the damp ground , as [they]586-they always did in such weather at that time of the year . It was impossible to advance in regular steps without crushing some of them at each tread . Though [Farmer Troutham]173-farmer troutham had just hurt [him]180-jude , [he]180-jude was [a boy who could not himself bear to hurt anything]587-a boy who could not himself bear to hurt anything . [He]180-jude had never brought [home]3897-home a nest of young birds without lying awake in misery half the night after , and often reinstating [them]586-they and the nest in [their]586-they original place the next morning . [He]180-jude could scarcely bear to see trees cut down or lopped , from a fancy that it hurt [them]589-them ; and late pruning , when the sap was up and the tree bled profusely , had been a positive grief to [him]180-jude in [his]180-jude infancy . This weakness of character , as it may be called , suggested that [he]180-jude was [the sort of man who was born to ache a good deal before the fall of the curtain upon [his]180-jude unnecessary life]590-the sort of man who was born to ache a good deal before the fall of the curtain upon his unnecessary life should signify that all was well with [him]180-jude again . [He]180-jude carefully picked [his]180-jude way on tiptoe among the earthworms , without killing a single one . On entering [the cottage]501-the cottage [he]180-jude found [[his]180-jude aunt]555-his aunt selling a penny loaf to [a little girl]593-a little girl , and when [the customer]594-the customer was gone [she]555-his aunt said , " Well , how do [you]180-jude come to be back here in the middle of the morning like this ? "[555-his aunt] " [I]555-his aunt 'm turned away . "[555-his aunt] " What ? "[555-his aunt] " [Mr. Troutham]176-mr troutham have turned [me]180-jude away because [I]180-jude let [the rooks]551-the rooks have a few peckings of corn . And there 's [my]180-jude wages - the last [I]180-jude shall ever hae ! "[180-jude] [He]180-jude threw the sixpence tragically on the table . " Ah ! And [she]555-his aunt opened upon [him]180-jude a lecture on how [she]555-his aunt would now have [him]180-jude all the spring upon [her]555-his aunt hands doing nothing . " If [you]180-jude ca n't skeer birds , what can [ye]180-jude do ? There ! do n't [ye]180-jude look so deedy ! "[596-her] [Jude]180-jude went out , and , feeling more than ever [his]180-jude existence to be an undemanded one , [he]180-jude lay down upon [his]180-jude back on a heap of litter near [the pig - sty]599-the pig - sty . The fog had by this time become more translucent , and the position of the sun could be seen through it . [He]180-jude pulled [his]180-jude straw hat over [his]180-jude face , and peered through the interstices of the plaiting at the white brightness , vaguely reflecting . Growing up brought responsibilities , [he]180-jude found . Events did not rhyme quite as [he]180-jude had thought . [Nature]179-nature 's logic was too horrid for [him]180-jude to care for . That mercy towards [one set of creatures]600-one set of creatures was cruelty towards another sickened [his]180-jude sense of harmony . As [you]601-you got older , and felt [yourself]601-you to be at the centre of [your]601-you time , and not at a point in its circumference , as [you]601-you had felt when [you]601-you were little , [you]601-you were seized with a sort of shuddering , [he]180-jude perceived . All around [you]601-you there seemed to be something glaring , garish , rattling , and the noises and glares hit upon the little cell called [your]601-you life , and shook it , and warped it . If [he]180-jude could only prevent [himself]180-jude growing up ! [He]180-jude did not want to be [a man]543-a man . Then , like [the natural boy]603-the natural boy , [he]180-jude forgot [his]180-jude despondency , and sprang up . During the remainder of the morning [he]180-jude helped [[his]180-jude aunt]555-his aunt , and in the afternoon , when there was nothing more to be done , [he]180-jude went into [the village]410-the village . Here [he]180-jude asked [a man whereabouts [Christminster]180-jude]606-a man whereabouts christminster lay . " [Christminster]180-jude ? "[607-the man] [The man]607-the man pointed north - eastward , in the very direction where lay [that field in which [Jude]180-jude had so disgraced [himself]180-jude]608-that field in which jude had so disgraced himself . There was something unpleasant about the coincidence for the moment , but the fearsomeness of this fact rather increased [his]180-jude curiosity about [the city]414-the city . [The farmer]526-the farmer had said [he]526-the farmer was never to be seen in [that field]611-that field again ; yet [Christminster]180-jude lay across [it]611-that field , and [the path]567-the path was a public one . So , stealing out of [the hamlet]613-the hamlet , [he]180-jude descended into [the same hollow which had witnessed [his]180-jude punishment in the morning , never swerving an inch from the path , and climbing up the long and tedious ascent on the other side]614-the same hollow which had witnessed his punishment in the morning , never swerving an inch from the path , and climbing up the long and tedious ascent on the other side till the track joined [the highway]615-the highway by a little clump of trees . Here [the ploughed land]616-the ploughed land ended , and all before [him]180-jude was bleak open down . [III]174-sue Not a soul was visible on [the hedgeless highway]617-the hedgeless highway , or on either side of it , and [the white road]618-the white road seemed to ascend and diminish till [it]618-the white road joined the sky . At the very top [it]618-the white road was crossed at right angles by a green " ridgeway "[174-sue] - [the Ickneild Street]11-the ickneild street and [original Roman road]619-original roman road through [the district]620-the district . [This ancient track]621-this ancient track ran east and west for many miles , and down almost to within living memory had been used for driving flocks and herds to fairs and markets . But [it]621-this ancient track was now neglected and overgrown . [The boy]437-the boy had never before strayed so far north as this from [the nestling hamlet in which [he]180-jude had been deposited by [the carrier]624-the carrier]623-the nestling hamlet in which he had been deposited by the carrier from [a railway station]625-a railway station southward , one dark evening some few months earlier , and till now [he]180-jude had had no suspicion that [such a wide , flat , low - lying country]626-such a wide , flat , low - lying country lay so near at hand , under the very verge of [[his]180-jude upland world]627-his upland world . [The whole northern semicircle between east and west]628-the whole northern semicircle between east and west , to a distance of forty or fifty miles , spread itself before [him]180-jude ; a bluer , moister atmosphere , evidently , than that [he]180-jude breathed up here . Not far from [the road]629-the road stood [a weather - beaten old barn of reddish - grey brick and tile]630-a weather - beaten old barn of reddish - grey brick and tile . [It]630-a weather - beaten old barn of reddish - grey brick and tile was known as [the Brown House by [the people of [the locality]633-the locality]632-the people of the locality]631-the brown house by the people of the locality . [He]180-jude was about to pass [it]630-a weather - beaten old barn of reddish - grey brick and tile when [he]180-jude perceived a ladder against the eaves ; and the reflection that the higher [he]180-jude got , the further [he]180-jude could see , led [Jude]180-jude to stand and regard [it]630-a weather - beaten old barn of reddish - grey brick and tile . On the slope of the roof [two men]634-two men were repairing the tiling . [He]180-jude turned into the ridgeway and drew towards [the barn]635-the barn . " Well , [[my]180-jude lad]3959-my lad , and what may [you]3959-my lad want up here ? "[180-jude] [The other tiler , glad of any kind of diversion from the monotony of]637-the other tiler , glad of any kind of diversion from the monotony of [his]637-the other tiler , glad of any kind of diversion from the monotony of labour , had also turned to look towards [the quarter designated]638-the quarter designated . " Ay - though [I]437-the boy should never ha ' thought of it [myself]437-the boy .... But [I]437-the boy ca n't see no [Christminster]180-jude to - day . "[437-the boy] [The boy]437-the boy strained [his]437-the boy eyes also ; yet neither could [he]437-the boy see [the far - off city]641-the far - off city . [He]437-the boy descended from [the barn]635-the barn , and abandoning [Christminster]180-jude with the versatility of [his]437-the boy age [he]437-the boy walked along [the ridge - track]643-the ridge - track , looking for any natural objects of interest that might lie in [the banks thereabout]644-the banks thereabout . When [he]437-the boy repassed [the barn]635-the barn to go back to [Marygreen]1-marygreen [he]437-the boy observed that the ladder was still in [its]646-its place , but that [the men]647-the men had finished [their]647-the men day 's work and gone away . It was waning towards evening ; there was still a faint mist , but it had cleared a little except in [the damper tracts of subjacent country]648-the damper tracts of subjacent country and along [the river - courses]649-the river - courses . [He]437-the boy thought again of [Christminster]180-jude , and wished , since [he]437-the boy had come two or three miles from [[[his]437-the boy aunt]555-his aunt 's house]651-his aunt 's house on purpose , that [he]437-the boy could have seen for once [this attractive city of which [he]437-the boy had been told]652-this attractive city of which he had been told . But even if [he]437-the boy waited [here]3898-here it was hardly likely that the air would clear before night . Yet [he]437-the boy was loth to leave [the spot]654-the spot , for [the northern expanse]655-the northern expanse became lost to view on retreating towards [the village]410-the village only a few hundred yards . [He]437-the boy ascended the ladder to have one more look at the point [the men]647-the men had designated , and perched [himself]437-the boy on the highest rung , overlying the tiles . [He]437-the boy might not be able to come so far as this for many days . Perhaps if [he]437-the boy prayed , the wish to see [Christminster]180-jude might be forwarded . [People]658-people said that , if [you]659-you prayed , things sometimes came to [you]659-you , even though [they]658-people sometimes did not . [He]437-the boy had read in a tract that [a man who had begun to build a church , and had no money to finish it]660-a man who had begun to build a church , and had no money to finish it , knelt down and prayed , and the money came in by the next post . [Another man]661-another man tried the same experiment , and the money did not come ; but [he]437-the boy found afterwards that the breeches [he]437-the boy knelt in were made by [a wicked Jew]662-a wicked jew . This was not discouraging , and turning on the ladder [Jude]180-jude knelt on the third rung , where , resting against [those above it]663-those above it , [he]180-jude prayed that the mist might rise . [He]437-the boy then seated [himself]437-the boy again , and waited . In the course of ten or fifteen minutes the thinning mist dissolved altogether from the northern horizon , as it had already done elsewhere , and about a quarter of an hour before the time of sunset the westward clouds parted , the sun 's position being partially uncovered , and the beams streaming out in visible lines between two bars of slaty cloud . [The boy]437-the boy immediately looked back in the old direction . Some way within the limits of [the stretch of landscape]665-the stretch of landscape , points of light like the topaz gleamed . The air increased in transparency with the lapse of minutes , till the topaz points showed themselves to be the vanes , windows , wet roof slates , and other shining spots upon the spires , domes , freestone - work , and varied outlines that were faintly revealed . It was [Christminster]180-jude , unquestionably ; either directly seen , or miraged in the peculiar atmosphere . [The spectator]666-the spectator gazed on and on till the windows and vanes lost their shine , going out almost suddenly like extinguished candles . [The vague city]667-the vague city became veiled in mist . Turning to the west , [he]437-the boy saw that the sun had disappeared . The foreground of the scene had grown funereally dark , and near objects put on the hues and shapes of [chimaeras]668-chimaeras . [He]437-the boy anxiously descended the ladder , and started homewards at a run , trying not to think of [giants]669-giants , [Herne the Hunter]183-herne the hunter , [Apollyon]184-apollyon lying in wait for [Christian]185-christian , or of [the captain with the bleeding hole in [his]670-the captain with the bleeding hole in his forehead and the corpses round him that remutinied every night on board the bewitched ship forehead and the corpses round [him]670-the captain with the bleeding hole in his forehead and the corpses round him that remutinied every night on board the bewitched ship that remutinied every night on board [the bewitched ship]671-the bewitched ship]670-the captain with the bleeding hole in his forehead and the corpses round him that remutinied every night on board the bewitched ship . [He]437-the boy knew that [he]437-the boy had grown out of belief in these horrors , yet [he]437-the boy was glad when [he]437-the boy saw [the church tower]672-the church tower and the lights in [the cottage]501-the cottage windows , even though this was not [the home of [his]437-the boy birth]674-the home of his birth , and [[his]437-the boy great - aunt]505-his great - aunt did not care much about [him]437-the boy . Inside and round about [[that old woman]676-that old woman 's ' shop]677-that old woman 's ' shop " window , with [its]3961-its twenty - four little panes set in lead - work , the glass of some of them oxidized with age , so that [you]3962-you could hardly see the poor penny articles exhibited within , and forming part of a stock which [a strong man]3963-a strong man could have carried , [Jude]180-jude had [his]437-the boy outer being for some long tideless time . But [his]437-the boy dreams were as gigantic as [his]437-the boy surroundings were small . Through the solid barrier of cold cretaceous upland to the northward [he]437-the boy was always beholding [a gorgeous city]3964-a gorgeous city - [the fancied place [he]437-the boy had likened to [the new Jerusalem]3966-the new jerusalem]3965-the fancied place he had likened to the new jerusalem , though there was perhaps more of [the painter]3967-the painter 's imagination and less of [the diamond merchant]3968-the diamond merchant 's in [his]437-the boy dreams thereof than in those of [the Apocalyptic writer]3969-the apocalyptic writer . And [the city]414-the city acquired a tangibility , a permanence , a hold on [his]437-the boy life , mainly from the one nucleus of fact that [the man]607-the man for whose knowledge and purposes [he]437-the boy had so much reverence was actually living [there]3887-there ; not only so , but living among [the more thoughtful and mentally shining ones therein]3973-the more thoughtful and mentally shining ones therein . In sad wet seasons , though [he]437-the boy knew it must rain at [Christminster]180-jude too , [he]437-the boy could hardly believe that it rained so drearily there . Whenever [he]437-the boy could get away from the confines of [the hamlet]613-the hamlet for an hour or two , which was not often , [he]437-the boy would steal off to [the Brown House on [the hill]564-the hill]3975-the brown house on the hill and strain [his]437-the boy eyes persistently ; sometimes to be rewarded by the sight of a dome or spire , at other times by a little smoke , which in [his]437-the boy estimate had some of the mysticism of incense . Then the day came when it suddenly occurred to [him]437-the boy that if [he]437-the boy ascended to the point of view after dark , or possibly went a mile or two further , [he]437-the boy would see the night lights of [the city]414-the city . It would be necessary to come back alone , but even that consideration did not deter [him]437-the boy , for [he]437-the boy could throw a little manliness into [his]437-the boy mood , no doubt . The project was duly executed . It was not late when [he]437-the boy arrived at [the place of outlook]3978-the place of outlook , only just after dusk , but [a black north - east]3979-a black north - east sky , accompanied by a wind from [the same quarter]3980-the same quarter , made the occasion dark enough . [He]437-the boy was rewarded ; but what [he]437-the boy saw was not the lamps in [rows]3981-rows , as [he]437-the boy had half expected . No individual light was visible , only a halo or glow - fog over - arching the place against the black heavens behind it , making the light and [the city]414-the city seem distant but a mile or so . [He]437-the boy set [himself]437-the boy to wonder on the exact point in the glow where [the schoolmaster]409-the schoolmaster might be - [he]409-the schoolmaster who never communicated with [anybody at [Marygreen]1-marygreen]3984-anybody at marygreen now ; who was as if dead to [them]3984-anybody at marygreen here . In the glow [he]437-the boy seemed to see [Phillotson]163-phillotson promenading at ease , like one of the forms in [[Nebuchadnezzar]186-nebuchadnezzar 's furnace]3985-nebuchadnezzar 's furnace . [He]437-the boy had heard that breezes travelled at the rate of ten miles an hour , and the fact now came into [his]437-the boy mind . [He]437-the boy parted [his]437-the boy lips as [he]437-the boy faced [the north - east]3986-the north - east , and drew in the wind as if it were a sweet liquor . "[678-you] [You]678-you , " [he]437-the boy said , addressing the breeze caressingly "[678-you] were in [Christminster city]679-christminster city between one and two hours ago , floating along [the streets]680-the streets , pulling round the weather - cocks , touching [Mr. Phillotson]163-phillotson 's face , being breathed by [him]163-phillotson ; and now [you]678-you are here , breathed by [me]0-i - [you]678-you , the very same . " Suddenly there came along this wind something towards [him]437-the boy - a message from [the place]3987-the place - from [some soul residing there]3988-some soul residing there , it seemed . Surely it was the sound of bells , the voice of [the city]414-the city , faint and musical , calling to [him]437-the boy , "[678-you] [We]681-they are happy here ! " [He]437-the boy had become entirely lost to [his]437-the boy bodily situation during this mental leap , and only got back to it by a rough recalling . A few yards below the brow of [the hill on which [he]437-the boy paused]3990-the hill on which he paused a team of horses made [its]3991-its appearance , having reached the place by dint of half an hour 's serpentine progress from the bottom of the immense declivity . [They]681-they had a load of coals behind [them]681-they - a fuel that could only be got into [the upland]523-the upland by this particular route . [They]681-they were accompanied by [a carter]3993-a carter , [a second man]3994-a second man , and [a boy , who now kicked a large stone behind one of the wheels]3995-a boy , who now kicked a large stone behind one of the wheels , and allowed the panting animals to have a long rest , while [those in charge]3996-those in charge took a flagon off the load and indulged in a drink round . [They]681-they were [elderly men , and had genial voices]3997-elderly men , and had genial voices . [Jude]180-jude addressed [them]681-they , inquiring if [they]681-they had come from [Christminster]180-jude . "[678-you] Heaven forbid , with this load ! " said [they]681-they . "[678-you] The place [I]0-i mean is that one yonder . " [He]180-jude was getting so romantically attached to [Christminster]180-jude that , like [a young lover]3998-a young lover alluding to [[his]180-jude mistress]3999-his mistress , [he]180-jude felt bashful at mentioning its name again . [He]180-jude pointed to the light in the sky - hardly perceptible to [their]681-they older eyes . "[678-you] Yes . There do seem a spot a bit brighter in [the nor'-east]13-the nor'-east than elsewhere , though [I]0-i should n't [ha]682-ha ' noticed it [myself]0-i , and no doubt it med be [Christminster]180-jude . " Here a little book of tales which [Jude]180-jude had tucked up under [his]180-jude arm , having brought [them]681-they to read on [his]180-jude way hither before it grew dark , slipped and fell into [the road]629-the road . [The carter]4001-the carter eyed [him]3930-young man while [he]4001-the carter picked it up and straightened the leaves . "[3930-young man] Ah , [young man]3930-young man , " [he]4001-the carter observed , "[3930-young man] [you]3930-young man 'd have to get [your]3930-young man head screwed on t'other way before [you]3930-young man could read what [they]684-they read there . " "[684-they] Why ? " asked [the boy]437-the boy . "[684-they] Oh , [they]684-they never look at anything that folks like [we]685-we can understand , " [the carter]4001-the carter continued , by way of passing the time . "[684-they] On'y foreign tongues used in the days of [the Tower of [Babel]15-babel]14-the tower of babel , when [no two families]686-no two families spoke alike . [They]684-they read that sort of thing as fast as a night - hawk will whir . ' Tis all learning there - nothing but learning , except religion . And that 's learning too , for [I]0-i never could understand it . Yes , ' tis a serious - minded place . Not but there 's [wenches in the streets o ' nights]687-wenches in the streets o ' nights ... [You]688-you know , [I]0-i suppose , that [they]684-they raise [pa'sons]689-pa'sons there like radishes in a bed ? And though it do take - how many years , [Bob]187-bob ? - five years to turn [a lirruping hobble - de - hoy chap]690-a lirruping hobble - de - hoy chap into [a solemn preaching man with no corrupt passions]691-a solemn preaching man with no corrupt passions , [they]684-they 'll do it , if it can be done , and polish un off like [the workmen]636-the workmen [they]684-they be , and turn [un]693-un out wi ' a long face , and a long black coat and waistcoat , and a religious collar and hat , same as [they]684-they used to wear in the Scriptures , so that [[his]187-bob own mother]694-his own mother would n't know [un]693-un sometimes .... There , ' tis [their]684-they business , like [anybody else]695-anybody else 's . " "[187-bob] But how should [you]187-bob know " "[187-bob] Now do n't [you]187-bob interrupt , [[my]0-i boy]696-my boy . Never interrupt [[your]187-bob senyers]697-your senyers . Move the fore hoss aside , [Bobby]187-bob ; here 's som'at coming ... [You]187-bob must mind that [I]0-i be a - talking of the college life . ' [Em]698-em lives on a lofty level ; there 's no gainsaying it , though [I]0-i [myself]0-i med not think much of 'em . As [we]699-we be here in [our]699-we bodies on this high ground , so be [they]684-they in [their]684-they minds - [noble - minded men]700-noble - minded men enough , no doubt - some on 'em - able to earn hundreds by thinking out loud . And [some on 'em]701-some on 'em be [strong young fellows that can earn a'most as much in silver cups]702-strong young fellows that can earn a'most as much in silver cups . As for music , there 's beautiful music everywhere in [Christminster]180-jude . [You]187-bob med be religious , or [you]187-bob med not , but [you]187-bob ca n't help striking in [your]187-bob homely note with the rest . And there 's [a street in [the place]3987-the place]703-a street in the place - [the main street]705-the main street - that ha'n't another like it in [the world]706-the world . [I]0-i should think [I]0-i did know a little about [Christminster]180-jude ! " By this time the horses had recovered breath and bent to [their]4004-their collars again . [Jude]180-jude , throwing a last adoring look at [the distant halo]4005-the distant halo , turned and walked beside [[his]180-jude remarkably well - informed friend , who had no objection to telling [him]180-jude as [they]4007-they moved on more yet of [the city]414-the city]4006-his remarkably well - informed friend , who had no objection to telling him as they moved on more yet of the city - [[its]414-the city towers and [halls]4010-halls and [churches]4011-churches]4009-its towers and halls and churches . "[0-i] Well , ' tis oonly what has come in [my]0-i way , " said [the carter]4001-the carter unboastfully . "[0-i] [I]0-i 've never been [there]3887-there , no more than [you]708-you ; but [I]0-i 've picked up the knowledge here and there , and [you]708-you be welcome to it . A - getting about [the world]706-the world as [I]0-i do , and mixing with [all classes of society]710-all classes of society , one ca n't help hearing of things . " [Jude]180-jude continued [his]180-jude walk homeward alone , pondering so deeply that [he]180-jude forgot to feel timid . [He]180-jude suddenly grew older . It had been the yearning of [his]180-jude heart to find something to anchor on , to cling to - for some place which [he]180-jude could call admirable . Should [he]180-jude find that place in [this city]4016-this city if [he]180-jude could get [there]3887-there ? Would [it]3887-there be a spot in which , without fear of [farmers]4018-farmers , or hindrance , or ridicule , [he]180-jude could watch and wait , and set [himself]180-jude to some mighty undertaking like [the men of old of whom [he]180-jude had heard]4019-the men of old of whom he had heard ? As the halo had been to [his]180-jude eyes when gazing at [it]714-a city of light a quarter of an hour earlier , so was the spot mentally to [him]180-jude as [he]180-jude pursued [his]180-jude dark way . "[0-i] It is [a city of light]714-a city of light , " [he]180-jude said to [himself]180-jude . "[0-i] The tree of knowledge grows [there]3887-there , " [he]180-jude added a few steps further on . "[0-i] [It]714-a city of light is a place that teachers of [men]716-men spring from and go to . " "[716-men] It is what [you]717-you may call [a castle , manned by scholarship and religion]718-a castle , manned by scholarship and religion . " After this figure [he]180-jude was silent a long while , till [he]180-jude added : "[716-men] It would just suit [me]0-i . " [IV Walking]188-jude somewhat slowly by reason of [his]180-jude concentration , [the boy]437-the boy - [an ancient man in some phases of thought]4021-an ancient man in some phases of thought , much younger than [his]180-jude years in others - was overtaken by [a light - footed pedestrian]4022-a light - footed pedestrian , whom , notwithstanding the gloom , [he]180-jude could perceive to be wearing an extraordinarily tall hat , a swallow - tailed coat , and a watch - chain that danced madly and threw around scintillations of sky - light as [its owner]4023-its owner swung along upon a pair of thin legs and noiseless boots . [Jude]188-jude , beginning to feel lonely , endeavoured to keep up with [him]189-vilbert . "[716-men] Well , [[my]0-i man]719-my man ! [I]0-i 'm in a hurry , so [you]719-my man 'll have to walk pretty fast if [you]719-my man keep alongside of [me]0-i . Do [you]719-my man know who [I]0-i am ? " "[719-my man] Yes , [I]0-i think . [Physician Vilbert]189-vilbert ? " "[189-vilbert] Ah - [I]0-i 'm known everywhere , [I]0-i see ! That comes of being [a public benefactor]720-a public benefactor . " [Vilbert]189-vilbert was [an itinerant quack - doctor]4024-an itinerant quack - doctor , well known to [the rustic population]4025-the rustic population , and absolutely unknown to [anybody else]695-anybody else , as [he]189-vilbert , indeed , took care to be , to avoid inconvenient investigations . [Cottagers]190-cottagers formed [[his]189-vilbert only patients]4027-his only patients , and [his]189-vilbert Wessex - wide repute was among [them]4027-his only patients alone . [His]189-vilbert position was humbler and [his]189-vilbert field more obscure than those of [the quacks with capital and an organized system of advertising]4028-the quacks with capital and an organized system of advertising . [He]189-vilbert was , in fact , [a survival]4029-a survival . The distances [he]189-vilbert traversed on foot were enormous , and extended nearly the whole length and breadth of [Wessex]10-wessex . [Jude]188-jude had one day seen [him]189-vilbert selling a pot of coloured lard to [an old woman]4030-an old woman as a certain cure for a bad leg , [the woman]4031-the woman arranging to pay a guinea , in instalments of a shilling a fortnight , for the precious salve , which , according to [the physician]4032-the physician , could only be obtained from a particular animal which grazed on [Mount Sinai]18-mount sinai , and was to be captured only at great risk to life and limb . [Jude]188-jude , though [he]188-jude already had [his]188-jude doubts about [this gentleman]4033-this gentleman 's medicines , felt [him]189-vilbert to be unquestionably [a travelled personage]4034-a travelled personage , and one who might be [a trustworthy source of information on matters not strictly professional]4035-a trustworthy source of information on matters not strictly professional . "[0-i] [I]0-i s'pose [you]0-i 've been to [Christminster]180-jude , [Physician]721-physician ? " "[721-physician] [I]0-i have - many times , " replied [the long thin man]4036-the long thin man . "[0-i] That 's one of [[my]0-i centres]722-my centres . " "[0-i] [It]180-jude 's [a wonderful city for scholarship and religion]723-a wonderful city for scholarship and religion ? " "[0-i] [You]0-i 'd say so , [[my]0-i boy]696-my boy , if [you]0-i 'd seen it . " "[729-we] And Greek ? " "[0-i] [I]0-i want to learn Latin and Greek [myself]0-i . " "[0-i] A lofty desire . [You]0-i must get a grammar of each tongue . " "[0-i] [I]0-i mean to go to [Christminster]180-jude some day .
