" "[0-i] Then [I]0-i must do it to - morrow morning . It wo n't keep . " "[0-i] Very well - do . " XI Next morning , which was Sunday , [she]945-every woman resumed operations about ten o'clock ; and the renewed work recalled the conversation which had accompanied it the night before , and put [her]945-every woman back into the same intractable temper . "[0-i] That 's the story about [me]0-i in [Marygreen]1-marygreen , is it - that [I]0-i entrapped ' [ee]948-ee ? Much of a catch [you]0-i were , [Lord send]949-lord send ! " As [she]945-every woman warmed [she]945-every woman saw some of [Jude]180-jude 's dear ancient classics on a table where they ought not to have been laid . "[949-lord send] [I]0-i wo n't have them books here in the way ! " [she]945-every woman cried petulantly ; and seizing them one by one [she]945-every woman began throwing them upon the floor . "[949-lord send] Leave [my]0-i books alone ! " [he]180-jude said . "[0-i] [You]0-i might have thrown them aside if [you]0-i had liked , but as to soiling them like that , it is disgusting ! " In the operation of making lard [Arabella]305-arabella 's hands had become smeared with the hot grease , and [her]305-arabella fingers consequently left very perceptible imprints on the book - covers . [She]945-every woman continued deliberately to toss the books severally upon the floor , till [Jude]180-jude , incensed beyond bearing , caught [her]945-every woman by the arms to make [her]945-every woman leave off . Somehow , in going so , [he]180-jude loosened the fastening of [her]945-every woman hair , and it rolled about [her]945-every woman ears . "[949-lord send] Let [me]0-i go ! " [she]945-every woman said . "[949-lord send] Promise to leave the books alone . " [She]945-every woman hesitated . "[949-lord send] Let [me]0-i go ! " [she]945-every woman repeated . "[949-lord send] Promise ! " After a pause : "[0-i] [I]0-i do . " [Jude]180-jude relinquished [his]180-jude hold , and [she]945-every woman crossed [the room]4227-the room to the door , out of which [she]945-every woman went with a set face , and into [the highway]615-the highway . Here [she]945-every woman began to saunter up and down , perversely pulling [her]945-every woman hair into a worse disorder than [he]180-jude had caused , and unfastening several buttons of [her]945-every woman gown . It was a fine Sunday morning , dry , clear and frosty , and the bells of [Alfredston Church]29-alfredston church could be heard on the breeze from the north . [People]658-people were going along [the road]629-the road , dressed in [their]658-people holiday clothes ; [they]658-people were mainly [lovers]798-lovers - such pairs as [Jude]180-jude and [Arabella]305-arabella had been when [they]658-people sported along [the same track some months earlier]4511-the same track some months earlier . [These pedestrians]4512-these pedestrians turned to stare at the extraordinary spectacle [she]945-every woman now presented , bonnetless , [her]945-every woman dishevelled hair blowing in the wind , [her]945-every woman bodice apart , [her]945-every woman sleeves rolled above [her]945-every woman elbows for [her]945-every woman work , and [her]945-every woman hands reeking with melted fat . [One of [the passers]4514-the passers]4513-one of the passers said in mock terror : "[0-i] [Good Lord]950-good lord deliver [us]951-their ! " "[950-good lord] See how [he]952-he 's served [me]0-i ! " [she]0-i cried . "[952-he] Making [me]0-i work Sunday mornings when [I]0-i ought to be going to [[my]0-i church]953-my church , and tearing [my]0-i hair off [my]0-i head , and [my]0-i gown off [my]0-i back ! " [Jude]180-jude was exasperated , and went out to drag [her]0-i in by main force . Then [he]180-jude suddenly lost [his]180-jude heat . [Illuminated]236-illuminated with the sense that all was over between [them]951-their , and that it mattered not what [she]0-i did , or [he]180-jude , [[her]0-i husband]3921-her husband stood still , regarding [her]0-i . [Their]951-their lives were ruined , [he]180-jude thought ; ruined by the fundamental error of [their]951-their matrimonial union : that of having based a permanent contract on a temporary feeling which had no necessary connection with affinities that alone render a lifelong comradeship tolerable . "[907-your father] Going to ill - use [me]0-i on principle , as [[your]954-your father]907-your father ill - used [[your]954-your mother]956-your mother , and [[[your]954-your father]907-your father 's sister]958-your father 's sister ill - used [[her]958-your father 's sister husband]3921-her husband ? " [she]0-i asked . "[954-your] All [you]954-your be a queer lot as [husbands]960-husbands and [wives]961-wives ! " [Jude]180-jude fixed an arrested , surprised look on [her]0-i . But [she]0-i said no more , and continued [her]0-i saunter till [she]0-i was tired . [He]180-jude left [the spot]654-the spot , and , after wandering vaguely a little while , walked in the direction of [Marygreen]1-marygreen . Here [he]180-jude called upon [[his]180-jude great - aunt]505-his great - aunt , whose infirmities daily increased . "[962-aunt] [Aunt]962-aunt - did [[my]0-i father]3941-my father ill - use [[my]0-i mother]964-my mother , and [[my]0-i aunt]965-my aunt [[her]965-my aunt husband]3921-her husband ? " said [Jude]180-jude abruptly , sitting down by the fire . [She]0-i raised [her]0-i ancient eyes under the rim of the by - gone bonnet that [she]0-i always wore . "[3941-my father] Who 's been telling [you]0-i that ? " [she]0-i said . "[3941-my father] [I]0-i have heard it spoken of , and want to know all . " "[3941-my father] [You]0-i med so well , [I]0-i s'pose ; though [[your]0-i wife]967-your wife - [I]0-i reckon ' twas [she]967-your wife - must have been a fool to open up that ! There is n't much to know after all . [[Your]0-i father]907-your father and [mother]4422-mother could n't get on together , and [they]970-they parted . It was coming [home]3897-home from [Alfredston market]972-alfredston market , when [you]0-i were [a baby]973-a baby - on [the hill by [the Brown House barn]4262-the brown house barn]974-the hill by the brown house barn - that [they]970-they had [their]970-they last difference , and took leave of [one another]976-one another for the last time . [[Your]0-i mother]956-your mother soon afterwards died - [she]956-your mother drowned [herself]956-your mother , in short , and [[your]0-i father]907-your father went away with [you]0-i to [South Wessex]30-south wessex , and never came [here]3898-here any more . " [Jude]180-jude recalled [[his]180-jude father]3903-his father 's silence about [North Wessex]23-north wessex and [[Jude]180-jude 's mother]4519-jude 's mother , never speaking of either till [his]180-jude dying day . "[907-your father] It was the same with [[[your]0-i father]907-your father 's sister]958-your father 's sister . [[Her]958-your father 's sister husband]3921-her husband offended [her]958-your father 's sister , and [she]958-your father 's sister so disliked living with [him]3921-her husband afterwards that [she]958-your father 's sister went away to [London]7-london with [[her]958-your father 's sister little maid]983-her little maid . [The Fawleys]175-the fawleys were not made for wedlock : it never seemed to sit well upon [us]984-our . There 's sommat in [our]984-our blood that wo n't take kindly to the notion of being bound to do what [we]984-our do readily enough if not bound . That 's why [you]0-i ought to have hearkened to [me]0-i , and not [ha]985-ha ' married . " "[0-i] Where did [Father]228-father and [Mother]229-mother part - by [the Brown House]790-the brown house , did [you]0-i say ? " "[0-i] A little further on - where [the road]629-the road to [Fenworth]31-fenworth branches off , and the handpost stands . A gibbet once stood there not onconnected with [our]984-our history . But let that be . " In the dusk of that evening [Jude]180-jude walked away from [[his]180-jude old aunt]4503-his old aunt 's as if to go [home]3897-home . But as soon as [he]180-jude reached the open down [he]180-jude struck out upon [it]4522-it till [he]180-jude came to [a large round pond]4523-a large round pond . The frost continued , though it was not particularly sharp , and the larger stars overhead came out slow and flickering . [Jude]180-jude put one foot on the edge of the ice , and then the other : it cracked under [his]180-jude weight ; but this did not deter [him]180-jude . [He]180-jude ploughed [his]180-jude way inward to the centre , the ice making sharp noises as [he]180-jude went . When just about the middle [he]180-jude looked around [him]180-jude and gave a jump . The cracking repeated itself ; but [he]180-jude did not go down . [He]180-jude jumped again , but the cracking had ceased . [Jude]180-jude went back to the edge , and stepped upon the ground . It was curious , [he]180-jude thought . What was [he]180-jude reserved for ? [He]180-jude supposed [he]180-jude was not [a sufficiently dignified person for suicide]4524-a sufficiently dignified person for suicide . Peaceful death abhorred [him]180-jude as [a subject]4525-a subject , and would not take [him]180-jude . What could [he]180-jude do of a lower kind than self - extermination ; what was there less noble , more in keeping with [his]180-jude present degraded position ? [He]180-jude could get drunk . Of course that was it ; [he]180-jude had forgotten . Drinking was the regular , stereotyped resource of [the despairing worthless]4526-the despairing worthless . [He]180-jude began to see now why [some men]4527-some men boozed at [inns]4528-inns . [He]180-jude struck down [the hill]564-the hill northwards and came to [an obscure public - house]4530-an obscure public - house . On entering and sitting down the sight of the picture of [Samson]225-samson and [Delilah]226-delilah on the wall caused [him]180-jude to recognize [the place]3987-the place as that [he]180-jude had visited with [Arabella]305-arabella on that first Sunday evening of [their]4532-their courtship . [He]180-jude called for liquor and drank briskly for an hour or more . Staggering homeward late that night , with all [his]180-jude sense of depression gone , and [his]180-jude head fairly clear still , [he]180-jude began to laugh boisterously , and to wonder how [Arabella]305-arabella would receive [him]180-jude in [his]180-jude new aspect . [The house]504-the house was in darkness when [he]180-jude entered , and in [his]180-jude stumbling state it was some time before [he]180-jude could get a light . Then [he]180-jude found that , though the marks of pig - dressing , of fats and scallops , were visible , the materials themselves had been taken away . A line written by [[his]180-jude wife]4427-his wife on the inside of an old envelope was pinned to the cotton blower of the fireplace : "[0-i] Have gone to [[my]0-i friends]944-my friends . Shall not return . " All the next day [he]180-jude remained at [home]3897-home , and sent off the carcase of the pig to [Alfredston]20-alfredston . [He]180-jude then cleaned up [the premises]4536-the premises , locked the door , put the key in a place [she]305-arabella would know if [she]305-arabella came back , and returned to [[his]180-jude masonry at [Alfredston]20-alfredston]4537-his masonry at alfredston . At night when [he]180-jude again plodded [home]3897-home [he]180-jude found [she]305-arabella had not visited [the house]504-the house . The next day went in the same way , and the next . Then there came a letter from [her]305-arabella . That [she]305-arabella had gone tired of [him]180-jude [she]305-arabella frankly admitted . [He]180-jude was such [a slow old coach]4540-a slow old coach , and [she]305-arabella did not care for the sort of life [he]180-jude led . There was no prospect of [his]180-jude ever bettering [himself]180-jude or [her]305-arabella . [She]305-arabella further went on to say that [[her]305-arabella parents]4299-her parents had , as [he]180-jude knew , for some time considered the question of emigrating to [Australia]32-australia , the pig - jobbing business being a poor one nowadays . [They]4299-her parents had at last decided to go , and [she]305-arabella proposed to go with [them]4299-her parents , if [he]180-jude had no objection . [A woman of [her]305-arabella sort]4542-a woman of her sort would have more chance over there than in [this stupid country]4543-this stupid country . [Jude]180-jude replied that [he]180-jude had not the least objection to [her]305-arabella going . [He]180-jude thought it a wise course , since [she]305-arabella wished to go , and one that might be to the advantage of both . [He]180-jude enclosed in the packet containing the letter the money that had been realized by the sale of the pig , with all [he]180-jude had besides , which was not much . From that day [he]180-jude heard no more of [her]305-arabella except indirectly , though [[her]305-arabella father]4197-her father and [[his]180-jude household]4545-his household did not immediately leave , but waited till [his]180-jude goods and other effects had been sold off . When [Jude]180-jude learnt that there was to be an auction at [the house of [the Donns]237-the donns]4546-the house of the donns [he]180-jude packed [his]180-jude own household goods into a waggon , and sent them to [her]305-arabella at [the aforesaid homestead]4547-the aforesaid homestead , that [she]305-arabella might sell them with the rest , or as many of them as [she]305-arabella should choose . [He]180-jude then went into lodgings at [Alfredston]20-alfredston , and saw in a shopwindow the little handbill announcing the sale of [[his]180-jude father - in - law]4548-his father - in - law 's furniture . [He]180-jude noted its date , which came and passed without [Jude]180-jude 's going near [the place]3987-the place , or perceiving that the traffic out of [Alfredston]20-alfredston by [the southern road]4550-the southern road was materially increased by the auction . A few days later [he]180-jude entered [a dingy broker 's shop]4551-a dingy broker 's shop in [the main street of [the town]4154-the town]4552-the main street of the town , and amid a heterogeneous collection of saucepans , a clothes - horse , rolling - pin , brass candlestick , swing looking - glass , and other things at the back of [the shop]4554-the shop , evidently just brought in from a sale , [he]180-jude perceived a framed photograph , which turned out to be [his]180-jude own portrait . It was one which [he]180-jude had had specially taken and framed by [a local man in bird's - eye maple]4555-a local man in bird's - eye maple , as a present for [Arabella]305-arabella , and had duly given [her]305-arabella on [their]4556-their wedding - day . On the back was still to be read , "[180-jude] [Jude]180-jude to [Arabella]305-arabella , " with the date . [She]305-arabella must have thrown it in with the rest of [her]305-arabella property at the auction . "[180-jude] Oh , " said [the broker]4557-the broker , seeing [him]180-jude look at this and the other articles in the heap , and not perceiving that the portrait was of [himself]0-i : "[180-jude] It is a small lot of stuff that was knocked down to [me]0-i at a cottage sale out on [the road to [Marygreen]1-marygreen]989-the road to marygreen . The frame is a very useful one , if [you]990-you take out the likeness . [You]990-you shall have it for a shilling . " The utter death of every tender sentiment in [[his]180-jude wife]4427-his wife , as brought [home]3897-home to [him]180-jude by this mute and undesigned evidence of [her]4427-his wife sale of [his]180-jude portrait and gift , was the conclusive little stroke required to demolish all sentiment in [him]180-jude . [He]180-jude paid the shilling , took the photograph away with [him]180-jude , and burnt it , frame and all , when [he]180-jude reached [[his]180-jude lodging]4560-his lodging . Two or three days later [he]180-jude heard that [Arabella]305-arabella and [[her]305-arabella parents]4299-her parents had departed . [He]180-jude had sent a message offering to see [her]305-arabella for a formal leave - taking , but [she]305-arabella had said that it would be better otherwise , since [she]305-arabella was bent on going , which perhaps was true . On the evening following [their]4562-their emigration , when [his]180-jude day 's work was done , [he]180-jude came out of doors after supper , and strolled in the starlight along [the too familiar road]4563-the too familiar road towards [the upland whereon had been experienced the chief emotions of [his]180-jude life]4564-the upland whereon had been experienced the chief emotions of his life . It seemed to be [his]180-jude own again . [He]180-jude could not realize [himself]180-jude . On [the old track]4565-the old track [he]180-jude seemed to be [a boy]4566-a boy still , hardly a day older than when [he]180-jude had stood dreaming at [the top of [that hill]4568-that hill]4567-the top of that hill , inwardly fired for the first time with ardours for [Christminster]180-jude and scholarship . "[990-you] Yet [I]0-i am [a man]543-a man , " [he]180-jude said . "[0-i] [I]0-i have [a wife]940-a wife . More , [I]0-i have arrived at the still riper stage of having disagreed with [her]940-a wife , disliked [her]940-a wife , had a scuffle with [her]940-a wife , and parted from [her]940-a wife . " [He]180-jude remembered then that [he]180-jude was standing not far from the spot at which the parting between [[his]180-jude father]3903-his father and [[his]180-jude mother]4570-his mother was said to have occurred . A little further on was the summit whence [Christminster]180-jude , or what [he]180-jude had taken for [that city]4132-that city , had seemed to be visible . [A milestone]4572-a milestone , now as always , stood at the roadside hard by . [Jude]180-jude drew near [it]4572-a milestone , and felt rather than read the mileage to [the city]414-the city . [He]180-jude remembered that once on [his]180-jude way [home]3897-home [he]180-jude had proudly cut with [his]180-jude keen new chisel an inscription on the back of that milestone , embodying [his]180-jude aspirations . It had been done in the first week of [his]180-jude apprenticeship , before [he]180-jude had been diverted from [his]180-jude purposes by [an unsuitable woman]4575-an unsuitable woman . [He]180-jude wondered if the inscription were legible still , and going to the back of [the milestone]4576-the milestone brushed away the nettles . By the light of a match [he]180-jude could still discern what [he]180-jude had cut so enthusiastically so long ago : THITHER J. F. with a pointing finger The sight of it , unimpaired , within its screen of grass and nettles , lit in [his]180-jude soul a spark of the old fire . Surely [his]180-jude plan should be to move onward through good and ill - to avoid morbid sorrow even though [he]180-jude did see uglinesses in [the world]706-the world ? Bene agere et loetari - to do good cheerfully - which [he]180-jude had heard to be the philosophy of [one Spinoza]238-one spinoza , might be [his]180-jude own even now . [He]180-jude might battle with [his]180-jude evil star , and follow out [his]180-jude original intention . By moving to a spot a little way off [he]180-jude uncovered the horizon in a north - easterly direction . There actually rose the faint halo , a small dim nebulousness , hardly recognizable save by the eye of faith . It was enough for [him]180-jude . [He]180-jude would go to [Christminster]180-jude as soon as the term of [his]180-jude apprenticeship expired . [He]180-jude returned to [[his]180-jude lodgings]4578-his lodgings in a better mood , and said [his]180-jude prayers . Part Second AT [CHRISTMINSTER]180-jude "[993-his] Save [his]993-his own soul [he]993-his hath no star . " - [SWINBURNE]239-swinburne . "[993-his] Notitiam primosque gradus vicinia fecit ; Tempore crevit amor . " - [OVID]240-ovid . [I]993-his The next noteworthy move in [Jude]180-jude 's life was that in which [he]180-jude appeared gliding steadily onward through a dusky landscape of some three years ' later leafage than had graced [his]180-jude courtship of [Arabella]305-arabella , and the disruption of [his]180-jude coarse conjugal life with [her]305-arabella . [He]180-jude was walking towards [Christminster City]33-christminster city , at a point a mile or two to [the south - west of [it]33-christminster city]4579-the south - west of it . [He]180-jude had at last found [himself]180-jude clear of [Marygreen]1-marygreen and [Alfredston]20-alfredston : [he]180-jude was out of [his]180-jude apprenticeship , and with [his]180-jude tools at [his]180-jude back seemed to be in the way of making a new start - the start to which , barring the interruption involved in [his]180-jude intimacy and married experience with [Arabella]305-arabella , [he]180-jude had been looking forward for about ten years . [Jude]180-jude would now have been described as [a young man with a forcible , meditative , and earnest rather than handsome cast of countenance]4580-a young man with a forcible , meditative , and earnest rather than handsome cast of countenance . [He]180-jude was of dark complexion , with dark harmonizing eyes , and [he]180-jude wore a closely trimmed black beard of more advanced growth than is usual at [his]180-jude age ; this , with [his]180-jude great mass of black curly hair , was some trouble to [him]180-jude in combing and washing out the stone - dust that settled on it in the pursuit of [his]180-jude trade . [His]180-jude capabilities in the latter , having been acquired in [the country]4234-the country , were of an all - round sort , including monumental stone - cutting , gothic free - stone work for the restoration of [churches]4011-churches , and carving of a general kind . In [London]7-london [he]994-he would probably have become specialized and have made [himself]994-he [a "[993-his] moulding mason]4583-a " moulding mason , " [a "[993-his] foliage sculptor " - perhaps a ' statuary]4584-a " foliage sculptor " - perhaps a ' statuary . "[994-he] [He]994-he had that afternoon driven in [a cart]995-a cart from [Alfredston]20-alfredston to [the village nearest [the city]414-the city]996-the village nearest the city in this direction , and was now walking the remaining four miles rather from choice than from necessity , having always fancied [himself]994-he arriving thus . The ultimate impulse to come had had a curious origin - one more nearly related to the emotional side of [him]994-he than to [the intellectual]998-the intellectual , as is often the case with [young men]859-young men . One day while in lodgings at [Alfredston]20-alfredston [he]994-he had gone to [Marygreen]1-marygreen to see [[his]994-he old aunt]4503-his old aunt , and had observed between the brass candlesticks on [her]4503-his old aunt mantlepiece the photograph of [a pretty girlish face , in a broad hat with radiating folds under the brim like the rays of a halo]1001-a pretty girlish face , in a broad hat with radiating folds under the brim like the rays of a halo . [He]994-he had asked who [she]4503-his old aunt was . [[His]994-he grand - aunt]1002-his grand - aunt had gruffly replied that [she]4503-his old aunt was [[his]994-he cousin]3917-his cousin [Sue Bridehead]174-sue , of [the inimical branch of [the family]3948-the family]1004-the inimical branch of the family ; and on further questioning [the old woman]1006-the old woman had replied that [the girl]4201-the girl lived in [Christminster]180-jude , though [she]1006-the old woman did not know where , or what [she]1006-the old woman was doing . [[His]994-he aunt]555-his aunt would not give [him]994-he the photograph . But it haunted [him]994-he ; and ultimately formed a quickening ingredient in [his]994-he latent intent of following [[his]994-he friend]1009-his friend [the school master thither]1010-the school master thither . [He]994-he now paused at the top of [a crooked and gentle declivity]1011-a crooked and gentle declivity , and obtained [his]994-he first near view of [the city]414-the city . Grey - stoned and dun - roofed , [it]1013-it stood within hail of the [Wessex]10-wessex border , and almost with the tip of one small toe within [it]1013-it , at the northernmost point of the crinkled line along which the leisurely Thames strokes [the fields of [that ancient kingdom]1015-that ancient kingdom]1014-the fields of that ancient kingdom . [The buildings]1016-the buildings now lay quiet in the sunset , a vane here and there on [their]1016-the buildings many spires and domes giving sparkle to a picture of sober secondary and tertiary hues . Reaching the bottom [he]994-he moved along the level way between pollard willows growing indistinct in the twilight , and soon confronted the outmost lamps of [the town]4154-the town - some of those lamps which had sent into the sky the gleam and glory that caught [his]994-he strained gaze in [his]994-he days of dreaming , so many years ago . [They]1018-they winked [their]1018-they yellow eyes at [him]994-he dubiously , and as if , though [they]1018-they had been awaiting [him]994-he all these years in disappointment at [his]994-he tarrying , [they]1018-they did not much want [him]994-he now . [He]994-he was [a species of Dick Whittington whose spirit was touched to finer issues than a mere material gain]1019-a species of dick whittington whose spirit was touched to finer issues than a mere material gain . [He]994-he went along [the outlying streets]1020-the outlying streets with the cautious tread of [an explorer]1021-an explorer . [He]994-he saw nothing of [the real city]1022-the real city in [the suburbs on this side]1023-the suburbs on this side . [His]994-he first want being [a lodging]1024-a lodging [he]994-he scrutinized carefully [such localities as seemed to offer on inexpensive terms the modest type of accommodation [he]994-he demanded]1025-such localities as seemed to offer on inexpensive terms the modest type of accommodation he demanded ; and after inquiry took [a room in [a suburb nicknamed " [Beersheba]34-beersheba]4586-a suburb nicknamed " beersheba]4585-a room in a suburb nicknamed " beersheba , "[994-he] though [he]994-he did not know this at the time . [Here]3898-here [he]994-he installed [himself]994-he , and having had some tea sallied forth . It was a windy , whispering , moonless night . To guide [himself]994-he [he]994-he opened under a lamp a map [he]994-he had brought . The breeze ruffled and fluttered it , but [he]994-he could see enough to decide on the direction [he]994-he should take to reach [the heart of [the place]3987-the place]1027-the heart of the place . After many turnings [he]994-he came up to [the first ancient mediaeval pile that [he]994-he had encountered]1029-the first ancient mediaeval pile that he had encountered . [It]1029-the first ancient mediaeval pile that he had encountered was [a college]1030-a college , as [he]994-he could see by the gateway . [He]994-he entered [it]1029-the first ancient mediaeval pile that he had encountered , walked round , and penetrated to dark corners which no lamplight reached . Close to [this college]1031-this college was another ; and a little further on another ; and then [he]994-he began to be encircled as it were with the breath and sentiment of [the venerable city]1032-the venerable city . When [he]994-he passed objects out of harmony with its general expression [he]994-he allowed [his]994-he eyes to slip over them as if [he]994-he did not see them . A bell began clanging , and [he]994-he listened till a hundred - and - one strokes had sounded . [He]994-he must have made a mistake , [he]994-he thought : it was meant for a hundred . When the gates were shut , and [he]994-he could no longer get into [the quadrangles]1033-the quadrangles , [he]994-he rambled under the walls and doorways , feeling with [his]994-he fingers the contours of their mouldings and carving . The minutes passed , [fewer and fewer people]1034-fewer and fewer people were visible , and still [he]994-he serpentined among the shadows , for had [he]994-he not imagined these scenes through ten bygone years , and what mattered a night 's rest for once ? High against the black sky the flash of a lamp would show crocketed pinnacles and indented battlements . Down [obscure alleys]1035-obscure alleys , apparently never trodden now by the foot of [man , and whose very existence seemed to be forgotten]1036-man , and whose very existence seemed to be forgotten , there would jut into [the path porticoes]1037-the path porticoes , oriels , doorways of enriched and florid middle - age design , [their]1038-their extinct air being accentuated by the rottenness of the stones . It seemed impossible that modern thought could house itself in [such decrepit and superseded chambers]1039-such decrepit and superseded chambers . Knowing [not a human being here]1040-not a human being here , [Jude]180-jude began to be impressed with the isolation of [his]180-jude own personality , as with a self - spectre , the sensation being that of one who walked but could not make [himself]994-he seen or heard . [He]180-jude drew [his]180-jude breath pensively , and , seeming thus almost [his]180-jude own ghost , gave [his]180-jude thoughts to the other ghostly presences with which the nooks were haunted . During the interval of preparation for this venture , since [[his]180-jude wife]4427-his wife and [furniture]1042-furniture 's uncompromising disappearance into space , [he]180-jude had read and learnt almost all that could be read and learnt by one in [his]180-jude position , of [the worthies who had spent [their]1043-the worthies who had spent their youth within these reverend walls , and whose souls had haunted them in their maturer age youth within these reverend walls , and whose souls had haunted [them]1043-the worthies who had spent their youth within these reverend walls , and whose souls had haunted them in their maturer age in [their]1043-the worthies who had spent their youth within these reverend walls , and whose souls had haunted them in their maturer age maturer age]1043-the worthies who had spent their youth within these reverend walls , and whose souls had haunted them in their maturer age . [Some of [them]1043-the worthies who had spent their youth within these reverend walls , and whose souls had haunted them in their maturer age]1044-some of them , by the accidents of [his]180-jude reading , loomed out in [his]180-jude fancy disproportionately large by comparison with the rest . The brushings of the wind against the angles , buttresses , and door - jambs were as the passing of [these only other inhabitants]1045-these only other inhabitants , the tappings of each ivy leaf on its neighbour were as the mutterings of [their]1043-the worthies who had spent their youth within these reverend walls , and whose souls had haunted them in their maturer age mournful souls , the shadows as their thin shapes in nervous movement , making [him]180-jude comrades in [his]180-jude solitude . In the gloom it was as if [he]180-jude ran against [them]1043-the worthies who had spent their youth within these reverend walls , and whose souls had haunted them in their maturer age without feeling [their]1043-the worthies who had spent their youth within these reverend walls , and whose souls had haunted them in their maturer age bodily frames . [The streets]680-the streets were now deserted , but on account of these things [he]180-jude could not go in . There were [poets abroad , of early date and of late]1047-poets abroad , of early date and of late , from [the friend and eulogist of [Shakespeare]241-shakespeare]1048-the friend and eulogist of shakespeare down to [him]241-shakespeare who has recently passed into silence , and that musical one of [the tribe who is still among [us]1050-us]1049-the tribe who is still among us . [Speculative philosophers]1051-speculative philosophers drew along , not always with wrinkled foreheads and hoary hair as in framed portraits , but pink - faced , slim , and active as in youth ; [modern divines]1052-modern divines sheeted in [their]1052-modern divines surplices , among whom the most real to [Jude Fawley]180-jude were [the founders of [the religious school called Tractarian]1054-the religious school called tractarian ; [the well - known three]1055-the well - known three , [the enthusiast]1056-the enthusiast , [the poet]1057-the poet , and [the formularist]1058-the formularist , the echoes of whose teachings had influenced [him]180-jude even in [[his]180-jude obscure home]1059-his obscure home]1053-the founders of the religious school called tractarian ; the well - known three , the enthusiast , the poet , and the formularist , the echoes of whose teachings had influenced him even in his obscure home . A start of aversion appeared in [his]180-jude fancy to move [them]1055-the well - known three at sight of [those other sons of [the place]3987-the place]1060-those other sons of the place , [the form in the full - bottomed wig]1062-the form in the full - bottomed wig , [statesman]1063-statesman , [rake]1064-rake , [reasoner]1065-reasoner , and [sceptic]1066-sceptic ; [the smoothly shaven historian so ironically civil to [Christianity]242-christianity]1067-the smoothly shaven historian so ironically civil to christianity ; with [others of the same incredulous temper]1068-others of the same incredulous temper , who knew [each quad]1069-each quad as well as [the faithful]1070-the faithful , and took equal freedom in haunting [its]1069-each quad cloisters . [He]180-jude regarded [the statesmen]1071-the statesmen in [their]1071-the statesmen various types , [men of firmer movement and less dreamy air]1072-men of firmer movement and less dreamy air ; [the scholar]1073-the scholar , [the speaker]4244-the speaker , [the plodder]1075-the plodder ; [the man whose mind grew with [his]180-jude growth in years]1076-the man whose mind grew with his growth in years , and [the man whose mind contracted with the same]1077-the man whose mind contracted with the same . [The scientists]1078-the scientists and [philologists]1079-philologists followed on in [his]180-jude mind - sight in an odd impossible combination , [men of meditative faces , strained foreheads , and weak - eyed as bats with constant research]1080-men of meditative faces , strained foreheads , and weak - eyed as bats with constant research ; then [official characters]1081-official characters - such men as [governor - generals]1082-governor - generals and [lord - lieutenants]1083-lord - lieutenants , in whom [he]180-jude took little interest ; [chief - justices]1084-chief - justices and [lord chancellors]1085-lord chancellors , [silent thin - lipped figures of whom [he]180-jude knew barely the names . A keener regard attached to [the prelates]1087-the prelates , by reason of [his]180-jude own former hopes]1086-silent thin - lipped figures of whom he knew barely the names . a keener regard attached to the prelates , by reason of his own former hopes . Of [them]1087-the prelates [he]180-jude had [an ample band]1088-an ample band - [some men of heart]1089-some men of heart , [others rather men of head]1090-others rather men of head ; [he]1091-he who apologized for [the Church]35-the church in Latin ; [the saintly author of the Evening Hymn]1092-the saintly author of the evening hymn ; and near [them]1087-the prelates [the great itinerant preacher]1093-the great itinerant preacher , [hymn - writer]1094-hymn - writer , and zealot , shadowed like [Jude]180-jude by [his]180-jude matrimonial difficulties . [Jude]180-jude found [himself]180-jude speaking out loud , holding conversations with [them]1087-the prelates as it were , like an actor in a melodrama who apostrophizes [the audience on the other side of the footlights]1095-the audience on the other side of the footlights ; till [he]180-jude suddenly ceased with a start at [his]180-jude absurdity . Perhaps those incoherent words of [the wanderer]1096-the wanderer were heard within the walls by [some student or thinker]1097-some student or thinker over [his]180-jude lamp ; and [he]180-jude may have raised [his]180-jude head , and wondered what voice it was , and what it betokened . [Jude]180-jude now perceived that , so far as solid flesh went , [he]180-jude had [the whole aged city]1098-the whole aged city to [himself]180-jude with the exception of [a belated townsman here and there]1099-a belated townsman here and there , and that [he]180-jude seemed to be catching a cold . A voice reached [him]180-jude out of the shade ; a real and local voice : " [You]180-jude 've been a - settin ' a long time on that plinth - stone , [young man]3930-young man . What med [you]180-jude be up to ? "[1100-a policeman who had been observing jude without the latter observing him] It came from [a policeman who had been observing [Jude]180-jude without [the latter]444-the latter observing [him]180-jude]1100-a policeman who had been observing jude without the latter observing him . [Jude]180-jude went [home]3897-home and to bed , after reading up a little about [these men]1103-these men and [their]1103-these men several messages to [the world]706-the world from a book or two that [he]180-jude had brought with [him]180-jude concerning [the sons of the university]1105-the sons of the university . As [he]180-jude drew towards sleep various memorable words of theirs that [he]180-jude had just been conning seemed spoken by [them]1103-these men in muttering utterances ; some audible , some unintelligible to [him]180-jude . One of the spectres who afterwards mourned [Christminster]180-jude as " [the home of lost causes]4588-the home of lost causes , "[180-jude] though [Jude]180-jude did not remember this was now apostrophizing [her]1106-her thus : " [Beautiful city]4589-beautiful city ! so venerable , so lovely , so unravaged by the fierce intellectual life of [our]4590-us century , so serene ! ... [Her]1106-her ineffable charm keeps ever calling [us]4590-us to the true goal of all of [us]4590-us , to the ideal , to perfection . "[1106-her] Another voice was that of [the Corn Law convert , whose phantom [he]180-jude had just seen in [the quadrangle]1108-the quadrangle with a great bell]1107-the corn law convert , whose phantom he had just seen in the quadrangle with a great bell . [Jude]180-jude thought [his]180-jude soul might have been shaping the historic words of [his]180-jude master - speech : " Sir , [I]180-jude may be wrong , but [my]180-jude impression is that [my]180-jude duty towards [a country threatened with famine]4591-a country threatened with famine requires that that which has been the ordinary remedy under all similar circumstances should be resorted to now , namely , that there should be free access to the food of [man]575-man from whatever quarter it may come ... Deprive [me]180-jude of office to - morrow , [you]4593-you can never deprive [me]180-jude of the consciousness that [I]180-jude have exercised the powers committed to [me]180-jude from no corrupt or interested motives , from no desire to gratify ambition , for no personal gain . "[180-jude] Then [the sly author of the immortal Chapter on Christianity]1109-the sly author of the immortal chapter on christianity : " How shall [we]1113-we excuse the supine inattention of the Pagan and philosophic world , to those evidences miracles which were presented by Omnipotence ? ... [The sages of [Greece]36-greece and [Rome]37-rome]4594-the sages of greece and rome turned aside from the awful spectacle , and appeared unconscious of any alterations in the moral or physical government of [the world]706-the world . "[1057-the poet] Then the shade of [the poet]1057-the poet , [the last of the optimists]1111-the last of the optimists : How [the world]706-the world is made for each of [us]1113-we ! And each of the Many helps to recruit The life of the race by a general plan . Then one of the three enthusiasts [he]1109-the sly author of the immortal chapter on christianity had seen just now , [the author of the Apologia]1114-the author of the apologia : " [My]1115-my argument was ... that absolute certitude as to the truths of natural theology was the result of an assemblage of concurring and converging probabilities ... that probabilities which did not reach to logical certainty might create a mental certitude . "[1115-my] The second of [them]1115-my , no polemic , murmured quieter things : Why should [we]1113-we faint , and fear to live alone , Since all alone , so [Heaven]234-heaven has will'd , [we]1113-we die ? [He]1109-the sly author of the immortal chapter on christianity likewise heard some phrases spoken by [the phantom with the short face]1116-the phantom with the short face , [the genial Spectator]1117-the genial spectator : " When [I]1117-the genial spectator look upon [the tombs of [the great]4597-the great]4596-the tombs of the great , every motion of envy dies in [me]1117-the genial spectator ; when [I]1117-the genial spectator read the epitaphs of [the beautiful]4598-the beautiful , every inordinate desire goes out ; when [I]1117-the genial spectator meet with the grief of [parents]4599-parents upon a tombstone , [my]1117-the genial spectator heart melts with compassion ; when [I]1117-the genial spectator see [the tombs of [the parents themselves]4601-the parents themselves]4600-the tombs of the parents themselves , [I]1117-the genial spectator consider the vanity of grieving for those whom [we]4602-we must quickly follow . "[1117-the genial spectator] And lastly [a gentle - voiced prelate]1118-a gentle - voiced prelate spoke , during whose meek , familiar rhyme , endeared to [him]1109-the sly author of the immortal chapter on christianity from earliest childhood , [Jude]180-jude fell asleep : Teach [me]0-i to live , that [I]0-i may dread The grave as little as [my]0-i bed . Teach [me]0-i to die ... [He]180-jude did not wake till morning . The ghostly past seemed to have gone , and everything spoke of to - day . [He]180-jude started up in bed , thinking [he]180-jude had overslept [himself]180-jude and then said : " By Jove - [I]180-jude had quite forgotten [[my]180-jude sweet - faced cousin]4603-my sweet - faced cousin , and that [she]4603-my sweet - faced cousin 's [here]3898-here all the time ! ... and [[my]180-jude old schoolmaster]4605-my old schoolmaster , too . "[180-jude] [His]180-jude words about [[his]180-jude schoolmaster]1119-his schoolmaster had , perhaps , less zest in them than [his]180-jude words concerning [[his]180-jude cousin]3917-his cousin . II Necessary meditations on the actual , including the mean bread - and - cheese question , dissipated the phantasmal for a while , and compelled [Jude]180-jude to smother high thinkings under immediate needs . [He]180-jude had to get up , and seek for work , manual work ; the only kind deemed by [many of [its]1122-its professors]1121-many of its professors to be work at all . Passing out into [the streets]680-the streets on this errand [he]180-jude found that [the colleges]727-the colleges had treacherously changed [their]727-the colleges sympathetic countenances : some were pompous ; [some]1125-some had put on the look of [family vaults above ground]1126-family vaults above ground ; something barbaric loomed in [the masonries of all]1127-the masonries of all . The spirits of [the great men]1128-the great men had disappeared . The numberless architectural pages around [him]180-jude [he]180-jude read , naturally , less as [an artist - critic of their forms]1129-an artist - critic of their forms than as [an artizan]1130-an artizan and comrade of [the dead handicraftsmen whose muscles had actually executed those forms]1131-the dead handicraftsmen whose muscles had actually executed those forms . [He]180-jude examined the mouldings , stroked them as one who knew [their]1132-their beginning , said they were difficult or easy in the working , had taken little or much time , were trying to the arm , or convenient to the tool . What at night had been perfect and ideal was by day the more or less defective real . Cruelties , insults , had , [he]180-jude perceived , been inflicted on [the aged erections]1133-the aged erections . The condition of several moved [him]180-jude as [he]180-jude would have been moved by [maimed sentient beings]1134-maimed sentient beings . [They]1134-maimed sentient beings were wounded , broken , sloughing off their outer shape in the deadly struggle against years , weather , and [man]575-man . The rottenness of these historical documents reminded [him]180-jude that [he]180-jude was not , after all , hastening on to begin the morning practically as [he]180-jude had intended . [He]180-jude had come to work , and to live by work , and the morning had nearly gone . It was , in one sense , encouraging to think that in [a place of crumbling stones]1136-a place of crumbling stones there must be plenty for one of [his]180-jude trade to do in the business of renovation . [He]180-jude asked [his]180-jude way to [the workyard of [the stone - mason whose name had been given [him]180-jude at [Alfredston]20-alfredston]1138-the stone - mason whose name had been given him at alfredston]1137-the workyard of the stone - mason whose name had been given him at alfredston ; and soon heard the familiar sound of the rubbers and chisels . [The yard]1139-the yard was a little centre of regeneration . Here , with keen edges and smooth curves , were forms in the exact likeness of those [he]180-jude had seen abraded and time - eaten on the walls . These were the ideas in modern prose which [the lichened colleges]1140-the lichened colleges presented in old poetry . Even some of those antiques might have been called prose when they were new . [They]1134-maimed sentient beings had done nothing but wait , and had become poetical . How easy to [the smallest building]1141-the smallest building ; how impossible to [most men]903-most men . [He]180-jude asked for [the foreman]1143-the foreman , and looked round among the new traceries , mullions , transoms , shafts , pinnacles , and battlements standing on the bankers half worked , or waiting to be removed . They were marked by precision , mathematical straightness , smoothness , exactitude : there in the old walls were the broken lines of the original idea ; jagged curves , disdain of precision , irregularity , disarray . For a moment there fell on [Jude]180-jude a true illumination ; that here in [the stone yard]1144-the stone yard was a centre of effort as worthy as that dignified by the name of scholarly study within the noblest of [the colleges]727-the colleges . But [he]180-jude lost it under stress of [his]180-jude old idea . [He]180-jude would accept any employment which might be offered [him]180-jude on the strength of [[his]180-jude late employer]1146-his late employer 's recommendation ; but [he]180-jude would accept it as a provisional thing only . This was [his]180-jude form of the modern vice of unrest . Moreover [he]180-jude perceived that at best only copying , patching and imitating went on [here]3898-here ; which [he]180-jude fancied to be owing to some temporary and local cause . [He]180-jude did not at that time see that mediaevalism was as dead as a fern - leaf in a lump of coal ; that other developments were shaping in the world around [him]180-jude , in which Gothic architecture and [its]1148-its associations had no place . The deadly animosity of contemporary logic and vision towards so much of what [he]180-jude held in reverence was not yet revealed to [him]180-jude . Having failed to obtain work [here]3898-here as yet [he]180-jude went away , and thought again of [[his]180-jude cousin]3917-his cousin , whose presence somewhere at hand [he]180-jude seemed to feel in wavelets of interest , if not of emotion . How [he]180-jude wished [he]180-jude had that pretty portrait of [her]3917-his cousin ! At last [he]180-jude wrote to [[his]180-jude aunt]555-his aunt to send it . [She]555-his aunt did so , with a request , however , that [he]180-jude was not to bring disturbance into [the family]3948-the family by going to see [the girl]4201-the girl or [[her]3917-his cousin relations]1154-her relations . [Jude]180-jude , [a ridiculously affectionate fellow]1155-a ridiculously affectionate fellow , promised nothing , put the photograph on the mantel - piece , kissed it - [he]180-jude did not know why - and felt more at [home]3897-home . [She]555-his aunt seemed to look down and preside over [his]180-jude tea . It was cheering - the one thing uniting [him]180-jude to the emotions of [the living city]1157-the living city . There remained [the schoolmaster]409-the schoolmaster - probably now [a reverend parson]1159-a reverend parson . But [he]180-jude could not possibly hunt up [such a respectable man]1160-such a respectable man just yet ; so raw and unpolished was [his]180-jude condition , so precarious were [his]180-jude fortunes . Thus [he]180-jude still remained in loneliness . Although [people]658-people moved round [him]180-jude [he]180-jude virtually saw none . Not as yet having mingled with the active life of [the place]3987-the place it was largely non - existent to [him]180-jude . But [the saints and prophets in the window]1163-the saints and prophets in the window - tracery , the paintings in [the galleries]1164-the galleries , the statues , the busts , the gargoyles , the corbel - heads - these seemed to breathe [his]180-jude atmosphere . Like [all newcomers]1165-all newcomers to [a spot on which the past]1166-a spot on which the past is deeply graven [he]180-jude heard that past announcing itself with an emphasis altogether unsuspected by , and even incredible to , [the habitual residents]1167-the habitual residents . For many days [he]180-jude haunted [the cloisters and quadrangles of [the colleges]727-the colleges]1168-the cloisters and quadrangles of the colleges at odd minutes in passing [them]1168-the cloisters and quadrangles of the colleges , surprised by impish echoes of [his]180-jude own footsteps , smart as the blows of a mallet . The Christminster ' sentiment , " as it had been called , ate further and further into [him]180-jude ; till [he]180-jude probably knew more about [those buildings]4606-those buildings materially , artistically , and historically , than [any one of [[their]4606-those buildings inmates]4608-their inmates]4607-any one of their inmates . It was not till now , when [he]180-jude found [himself]180-jude actually on the spot of [his]180-jude enthusiasm , that [Jude]180-jude perceived how far away from the object of that enthusiasm [he]180-jude really was . Only a wall divided [him]180-jude from [those happy young contemporaries of [his]180-jude with whom [he]180-jude shared a common mental life]4609-those happy young contemporaries of his with whom he shared a common mental life ; [men who had nothing to do from morning till night but to read , mark , learn , and inwardly digest]4610-men who had nothing to do from morning till night but to read , mark , learn , and inwardly digest . Only a wall - but what a wall ! Every day , every hour , as [he]180-jude went in search of labour , [he]180-jude saw [them]4606-those buildings going and coming also , rubbed shoulders with [them]4606-those buildings , heard [their]4606-those buildings voices , marked [their]4606-those buildings movements . The conversation of some of [the more thoughtful among [them]4606-those buildings]4611-the more thoughtful among them seemed oftentimes , owing to [his]180-jude long and persistent preparation for this place , to be peculiarly akin to [his]180-jude own thoughts . Yet [he]180-jude was as far from [them]4606-those buildings as if [he]180-jude had been at the antipodes . Of course [he]180-jude was . [He]180-jude was [a young workman in a white blouse]4612-a young workman in a white blouse , and with stone - dust in the creases of [his]180-jude clothes ; and in passing [him]180-jude [they]4606-those buildings did not even see [him]180-jude , or hear [him]180-jude , rather saw through [him]180-jude as through a pane of glass at [their]4606-those buildings familiars beyond . Whatever [they]4606-those buildings were to [him]180-jude , [he]180-jude to [them]4606-those buildings was not on the spot at all ; and yet [he]180-jude had fancied [he]180-jude would be close to [their]4606-those buildings lives by coming there . But the future lay ahead after all ; and if [he]180-jude could only be so fortunate as to get into good employment [he]180-jude would put up with the inevitable . So [he]180-jude thanked [God]177-god for [his]180-jude health and strength , and took courage . For the present [he]180-jude was outside the gates of everything , colleges included : perhaps some day [he]180-jude would be inside . [Those palaces of light and leading]4613-those palaces of light and leading ; [he]180-jude might some day look down on [the world]706-the world through their panes . At length [he]180-jude did receive a message from [[the stone - mason]4615-the stone - mason 's yard]4616-the stone - mason 's yard - that a job was waiting for [him]180-jude . It was [his]180-jude first encouragement , and [he]180-jude closed with the offer promptly . [He]180-jude was young and strong , or [he]180-jude never could have executed with such zest the undertakings to which [he]180-jude now applied [himself]180-jude , since they involved reading most of the night after working all the day . First [he]180-jude bought a shaded lamp for four and six - pence , and obtained a good light . Then [he]180-jude got pens , paper , and such other necessary books as [he]180-jude had been unable to obtain elsewhere . Then , to the consternation of [[his]180-jude landlady]4617-his landlady , [he]180-jude shifted all the furniture of [[his]180-jude room]4314-his room - a single one for living and sleeping - rigged up a curtain on a rope across the middle , to make a double chamber out of one , hung up a thick blind that [nobody]4069-nobody should know how [he]180-jude was curtailing the hours of sleep , laid out [his]180-jude books , and sat down . Having been deeply encumbered by marrying , getting [a cottage]4620-a cottage , and buying the furniture which had disappeared in the wake of [[his]180-jude wife]4427-his wife , [he]180-jude had never been able to save any money since the time of those disastrous ventures , and till [his]180-jude wages began to come in [he]180-jude was obliged to live in the narrowest way . After buying a book or two [he]180-jude could not even afford [himself]180-jude a fire ; and when the nights reeked with the raw and cold air from [the Meadows]39-the meadows [he]180-jude sat over [his]180-jude lamp in a great - coat , hat , and woollen gloves . From [his]180-jude window [he]180-jude could perceive the spire of [the cathedral]4622-the cathedral , and the ogee dome under which resounded the great bell of [the city]414-the city . [The tall tower]4624-the tall tower , tall belfry windows , and tall pinnacles of [the college]4625-the college by [the bridge]4202-the bridge [he]180-jude could also get a glimpse of by going to the staircase . These objects [he]180-jude used as stimulants when [his]180-jude faith in the future was dim . Like [enthusiasts in general]4627-enthusiasts in general [he]180-jude made no inquiries into details of procedure . Picking up general notions from casual acquaintance , [he]180-jude never dwelt upon them . For the present , [he]180-jude said to [himself]180-jude , the one thing necessary was to get ready by accumulating money and knowledge , and await whatever chances were afforded to such an one of becoming [a son of the University]4628-a son of the university . "[180-jude] For wisdom is a defence , and money is a defence ; but the excellency of knowledge is , that wisdom giveth life to [them]1170-them that have it . " [His]180-jude desire absorbed [him]180-jude , and left no part of [him]180-jude to weigh its practicability . At this time [he]180-jude received a nervously anxious letter from [[his]180-jude poor old aunt]4629-his poor old aunt , on the subject which had previously distressed [her]4629-his poor old aunt - a fear that [Jude]180-jude would not be strong - minded enough to keep away from [[his]180-jude cousin]3917-his cousin [Sue Bridehead]174-sue and [[her]174-sue relations]1154-her relations . [[Sue]174-sue 's father]4632-sue 's father , [[his]180-jude aunt]555-his aunt believed , had gone back to [London]7-london , but [the girl]4201-the girl remained at [Christminster]180-jude . To make [her]4201-the girl still more objectionable [she]4201-the girl was an artist or designer of some sort in what was called [an ecclesiastical warehouse]4635-an ecclesiastical warehouse , which was a perfect seed - bed of idolatry , and [she]4201-the girl was no doubt abandoned to [mummeries on that account]4636-mummeries on that account - if not quite [a Papist]4637-a papist . [Miss Drusilla Fawley]167-drusilla fawley was of [her]167-drusilla fawley date , [Evangelical]243-evangelical . As [Jude]180-jude was rather on an intellectual track than a theological , this news of [Sue]174-sue 's probable opinions did not much influence [him]180-jude one way or the other , but the clue to [her]4201-the girl whereabouts was decidedly interesting . With an altogether singular pleasure [he]180-jude walked at [his]180-jude earliest spare minutes past [the shops answering to [[his]180-jude great - aunt]505-his great - aunt 's description]4638-the shops answering to his great - aunt 's description ; and beheld in one of [them]4638-the shops answering to his great - aunt 's description [a young girl sitting behind a desk , who was suspiciously like [the original of the portrait]4641-the original of the portrait]4640-a young girl sitting behind a desk , who was suspiciously like the original of the portrait . [He]180-jude ventured to enter on a trivial errand , and having made [his]180-jude purchase lingered on the scene . [The shop]4554-the shop seemed to be kept entirely by [women]3879-women . [It]4554-the shop contained Anglican books , stationery , texts , and fancy goods : little plaster angels on brackets , Gothic - framed pictures of saints , ebony crosses that were almost crucifixes , prayer - books that were almost missals . [He]180-jude felt very shy of looking at [the girl in the desk]4644-the girl in the desk ; [she]4644-the girl in the desk was so pretty that [he]180-jude could not believe it possible that [she]4644-the girl in the desk should belong to [him]180-jude . Then [she]4644-the girl in the desk spoke to one of [the two older women behind the counter]4645-the two older women behind the counter ; and [he]180-jude recognized in the accents certain qualities of [his]180-jude own voice ; softened and sweetened , but [his]180-jude own . What was [she]4644-the girl in the desk doing ? [He]180-jude stole a glance round . Before [her]4644-the girl in the desk lay a piece of zinc , cut to the shape of a scroll three or four feet long , and coated with a dead - surface paint on one side . Hereon [she]4644-the girl in the desk was designing or illuminating , in characters of Church text , the single word A L L E L U J A "[1171-hers] A sweet , saintly , Christian business , [hers]1171-hers ! " thought [he]180-jude . [Her]4644-the girl in the desk presence [here]3898-here was now fairly enough explained , [her]4644-the girl in the desk skill in work of this sort having no doubt been acquired from [[her]4644-the girl in the desk father]4197-her father 's occupation as [an ecclesiastical worker in metal]4139-an ecclesiastical worker in metal . The lettering on which [she]4644-the girl in the desk was engaged was clearly intended to be fixed up in some chancel to assist devotion . [He]180-jude came out . It would have been easy to speak to [her]4644-the girl in the desk there and then , but it seemed scarcely honourable towards [[his]180-jude aunt]555-his aunt to disregard [her]4644-the girl in the desk request so incontinently . [She]4644-the girl in the desk had used [him]180-jude roughly , but [she]4644-the girl in the desk had brought [him]180-jude up : and the fact of [her]4644-the girl in the desk being powerless to control [him]180-jude lent a pathetic force to a wish that would have been inoperative as an argument . So [Jude]180-jude gave no sign . [He]180-jude would not call upon [Sue]174-sue just yet . [He]180-jude had other reasons against doing so when [he]180-jude had walked away . [She]4644-the girl in the desk seemed so dainty beside [himself]180-jude in [his]180-jude rough working - jacket and dusty trousers that [he]180-jude felt [he]180-jude was as yet unready to encounter [her]4644-the girl in the desk , as [he]180-jude had felt about [Mr. Phillotson]163-phillotson . And how possible it was that [she]4644-the girl in the desk had inherited the antipathies of [[her]4644-the girl in the desk family]4650-her family , and would scorn [him]180-jude , as far as [a Christian]4489-a christian could , particularly when [he]180-jude had told [her]4644-the girl in the desk that unpleasant part of [his]180-jude history which had resulted in [his]180-jude becoming enchained to one of [her]4644-the girl in the desk own sex whom [she]4644-the girl in the desk would certainly not admire . Thus [he]180-jude kept watch over [her]4644-the girl in the desk , and liked to feel [she]4644-the girl in the desk was there . The consciousness of [her]4644-the girl in the desk living presence stimulated [him]180-jude . But [she]4644-the girl in the desk remained more or less an ideal character , about whose form [he]180-jude began to weave curious and fantastic day - dreams . Between two and three weeks afterwards [Jude]180-jude was engaged with [some more men]4652-some more men , outside [Crozier College]40-crozier college in [Old - time Street]41-old - time street , in getting a block of worked freestone from a waggon across [the pavement]4653-the pavement , before hoisting it to the parapet which [they]4652-some more men were repairing . Standing in position [the head man]4654-the head man said , "[1171-hers] Spaik when [he]1172-he heave ! [He]1172-he - ho ! " And [they]4652-some more men heaved . All of a sudden , as [he]180-jude lifted , [[his]180-jude cousin]3917-his cousin stood close to [his]180-jude elbow , pausing a moment on the bend of [her]4644-the girl in the desk foot till the obstructing object should have been removed . [She]4644-the girl in the desk looked right into [his]180-jude face with liquid , untranslatable eyes , that combined , or seemed to [him]180-jude to combine , keenness with tenderness , and mystery with both , [their]4652-some more men expression , as well as that of [her]4644-the girl in the desk lips , taking its life from some words just spoken to [a companion]4656-a companion , and being carried on into [his]180-jude face quite unconsciously . [She]4644-the girl in the desk no more observed [his]180-jude presence than that of the dust - motes which [his]180-jude manipulations raised into the sunbeams . [His]180-jude closeness to [her]4644-the girl in the desk was so suggestive that [he]180-jude trembled , and turned [his]180-jude face away with a shy instinct to prevent [her]4644-the girl in the desk recognizing [him]180-jude , though as [she]4644-the girl in the desk had never once seen [him]180-jude [she]4644-the girl in the desk could not possibly do so ; and might very well never have heard even [his]180-jude name . [He]180-jude could perceive that though [she]4644-the girl in the desk was [a country - girl at bottom]4657-a country - girl at bottom , [a latter girlhood of some years in [London]7-london]4658-a latter girlhood of some years in london , and a womanhood here , had taken all rawness out of [her]4644-the girl in the desk . When [she]4644-the girl in the desk was gone [he]180-jude continued [his]180-jude work , reflecting on [her]4644-the girl in the desk . [He]180-jude had been so caught by [her]4644-the girl in the desk influence that [he]180-jude had taken no count of [her]4644-the girl in the desk general mould and build . [He]180-jude remembered now that [she]4644-the girl in the desk was not a large figure , that [she]4644-the girl in the desk was light and slight , of the type dubbed elegant . That was about all [he]180-jude had seen . There was nothing statuesque in [her]4644-the girl in the desk ; all was nervous motion . [She]4644-the girl in the desk was mobile , living , yet [a painter]4659-a painter might not have called [her]4644-the girl in the desk handsome or beautiful . But the much that [she]4644-the girl in the desk was surprised [him]180-jude . [She]4644-the girl in the desk was quite a long way removed from the rusticity that was [his]180-jude . How could [one of [his]180-jude cross - grained , unfortunate , almost accursed stock]4660-one of his cross - grained , unfortunate , almost accursed stock , have contrived to reach this pitch of niceness ? [London]7-london had done it , [he]180-jude supposed . From this moment the emotion which had been accumulating in [his]180-jude breast as the bottled - up effect of solitude and the poetized locality [he]180-jude dwelt in , insensibly began to precipitate itself on this half - visionary form ; and [he]180-jude perceived that , whatever [his]180-jude obedient wish in a contrary direction , [he]180-jude would soon be unable to resist the desire to make [himself]180-jude known to [her]4644-the girl in the desk . [He]180-jude affected to think of [her]4644-the girl in the desk quite in a family way , since there were crushing reasons why [he]180-jude should not and could not think of [her]4644-the girl in the desk in any other . The first reason was that [he]180-jude was married , and it would be wrong . The second was that [they]4661-they were [cousins]4662-cousins . It was not well for [cousins]4662-cousins to fall in love even when circumstances seemed to favour the passion . The third : even were [he]180-jude free , in [a family like [his]180-jude own]4664-a family like his own where marriage usually meant a tragic sadness , marriage with [a blood - relation]4665-a blood - relation would duplicate the adverse conditions , and a tragic sadness might be intensified to a tragic horror . Therefore , again , [he]180-jude would have to think of [Sue]174-sue with only [a relation]4666-a relation 's mutual interest in one belonging to [him]180-jude ; regard [her]4644-the girl in the desk in a practical way as [some one to be proud of]4667-some one to be proud of ; to talk and nod to ; later on , to be invited to tea by , the emotion spent on [her]4644-the girl in the desk being rigorously that of [a kinsman and well - wisher]4668-a kinsman and well - wisher . So would [she]4644-the girl in the desk be to [him]180-jude a kindly star , an elevating power , [a companion in Anglican worship]4669-a companion in anglican worship , [a tender friend]4670-a tender friend . III But under the various deterrent influences [Jude]180-jude 's instinct was to approach [her]4644-the girl in the desk timidly , and the next Sunday [he]180-jude went to the morning service in [the Cathedral church of [Cardinal College]42-cardinal college]4671-the cathedral church of cardinal college to gain a further view of [her]4644-the girl in the desk , for [he]180-jude had found that [she]4644-the girl in the desk frequently attended [there]3887-there . [She]4644-the girl in the desk did not come , and [he]180-jude awaited [her]4644-the girl in the desk in the afternoon , which was finer . [He]180-jude knew that if [she]4644-the girl in the desk came at all [she]4644-the girl in the desk would approach [the building along the eastern side of [the great green quadrangle from which [it]4673-the building along the eastern side of the great green quadrangle from which it was accessible was accessible]4674-the great green quadrangle from which it was accessible]4673-the building along the eastern side of the great green quadrangle from which it was accessible , and [he]180-jude stood in a corner while the bell was going . A few minutes before the hour for service [she]4644-the girl in the desk appeared as [one of [the figures walking along under the college walls]4676-the figures walking along under the college walls]4675-one of the figures walking along under the college walls , and at sight of [her]4644-the girl in the desk [he]180-jude advanced up the side opposite , and followed [her]4644-the girl in the desk into [the building]4677-the building , more than ever glad that [he]180-jude had not as yet revealed [himself]180-jude . To see [her]4644-the girl in the desk , and to be [himself]180-jude unseen and unknown , was enough for [him]180-jude at present . [He]180-jude lingered awhile in [the vestibule]4678-the vestibule , and the service was some way advanced when [he]180-jude was put into a seat . It was a louring , mournful , still afternoon , when a religion of some sort seems a necessity to [ordinary practical men]4679-ordinary practical men , and not only a luxury of the emotional and leisured classes . In the dim light and the baffling glare of the clerestory windows [he]180-jude could discern [the opposite worshippers]4680-the opposite worshippers indistinctly only , but [he]180-jude saw that [Sue]174-sue was among [them]4680-the opposite worshippers . [He]180-jude had not long discovered the exact seat that [she]4644-the girl in the desk occupied when the chanting of the 119th Psalm in which [the choir]4681-the choir was engaged reached its second part , In quo corriget , the organ changing to a pathetic Gregorian tune as [the singers]4682-the singers gave forth : Wherewithal shall [a young man]4683-a young man cleanse [his]4683-a young man way ? It was the very question that was engaging [Jude]180-jude 's attention at this moment . What [a wicked worthless fellow]4684-a wicked worthless fellow [he]180-jude had been to give vent as [he]180-jude had done to an animal passion for [a woman]4193-a woman , and allow it to lead to such disastrous consequences ; then to think of putting an end to [himself]180-jude ; then to go recklessly and get drunk . The great waves of pedal music tumbled round [the choir]4681-the choir , and , nursed on the supernatural as [he]180-jude had been , it is not wonderful that [he]180-jude could hardly believe that the psalm was not specially set by [some regardful Providence]4687-some regardful providence for this moment of [his]180-jude first entry into [the solemn building]4688-the solemn building . And yet it was the ordinary psalm for the twenty - fourth evening of the month . [The girl for whom [he]180-jude was beginning to nourish an extraordinary tenderness]4689-the girl for whom he was beginning to nourish an extraordinary tenderness was at this time ensphered by the same harmonies as those which floated into [his]180-jude ears ; and the thought was a delight to [him]180-jude . [She]4689-the girl for whom he was beginning to nourish an extraordinary tenderness was probably [a frequenter of [this place]3919-this place]4690-a frequenter of this place , and , steeped body and soul in church sentiment as [she]4689-the girl for whom he was beginning to nourish an extraordinary tenderness must be by occupation and habit , had , no doubt , much in common with [him]180-jude . To [an impressionable and lonely young man]4692-an impressionable and lonely young man the consciousness of having at last found anchorage for [his]180-jude thoughts , which promised to supply both social and spiritual possibilities , was like the dew of [Hermon]244-hermon , and [he]180-jude remained throughout the service in a sustaining atmosphere of ecstasy . Though [he]180-jude was loth to suspect it , [some people]884-some people might have said to [him]180-jude that the atmosphere blew as distinctly from [Cyprus]43-cyprus as from [Galilee]44-galilee . [Jude]180-jude waited till [she]4689-the girl for whom he was beginning to nourish an extraordinary tenderness had left [her]4689-the girl for whom he was beginning to nourish an extraordinary tenderness seat and passed under the screen before [he]180-jude [himself]180-jude moved . [She]4689-the girl for whom he was beginning to nourish an extraordinary tenderness did not look towards [him]180-jude , and by the time [he]180-jude reached the door [she]4689-the girl for whom he was beginning to nourish an extraordinary tenderness was half - way down [the broad path]4694-the broad path . Being dressed up in [his]180-jude Sunday suit [he]180-jude was inclined to follow [her]4689-the girl for whom he was beginning to nourish an extraordinary tenderness and reveal [himself]180-jude . But [he]180-jude was not quite ready ; and , alas , ought [he]180-jude to do so with the kind of feeling that was awakening in [him]180-jude ? For though it had seemed to have an ecclesiastical basis during the service , and [he]180-jude had persuaded [himself]180-jude that such was the case , [he]180-jude could not altogether be blind to the real nature of the magnetism . [She]4689-the girl for whom he was beginning to nourish an extraordinary tenderness was such [a stranger]510-a stranger that the kinship was affectation , and [he]180-jude said , "[1172-he] It ca n't be ! [I]0-i , [a man with [a wife]940-a wife]1173-a man with a wife , must not know [her]940-a wife ! " Still [Sue]174-sue WAS [[his]180-jude own kin]4696-his own kin , and the fact of [his]180-jude having [a wife]940-a wife , even though [she]174-sue was not in evidence in this hemisphere , might be a help in one sense . It would put all thought of a tender wish on [his]180-jude part out of [Sue]174-sue 's mind , and make [her]174-sue intercourse with [him]180-jude free and fearless . It was with some heartache that [he]180-jude saw how little [he]180-jude cared for the freedom and fearlessness that would result in [her]174-sue from such knowledge . Some little time before the date of this service in [the cathedral]4622-the cathedral [the pretty , liquid - eyed , light - footed young woman [Sue Bridehead]174-sue]4699-the pretty , liquid - eyed , light - footed young woman sue bridehead had an afternoon 's holiday , and leaving [the ecclesiastical establishment in which [she]174-sue not only assisted but lodged]4700-the ecclesiastical establishment in which she not only assisted but lodged , took a walk into [the country]4234-the country with a book in [her]174-sue hand . It was one of those cloudless days which sometimes occur in [Wessex]10-wessex and elsewhere between days of cold and wet , as if intercalated by caprice of [the weather - god]4702-the weather - god . [She]174-sue went along for a mile or two until [she]174-sue came to much higher ground than that of [[the city]414-the city [she]174-sue had left behind [her]174-sue]4704-the city she had left behind her . [The road]629-the road passed between [green fields]4706-green fields , and coming to [a stile]4707-a stile [Sue]174-sue paused there , to finish the page [she]174-sue was reading , and then looked back at [the towers]4708-the towers and domes and pinnacles new and old . On the other side of [the stile]4709-the stile , in the footpath , [she]174-sue beheld [a foreigner with black hair and a sallow face]4710-a foreigner with black hair and a sallow face , sitting on the grass beside a large square board whereon were fixed , as closely as [they]4711-they could stand , a number of plaster statuettes , some of them bronzed , which [he]4710-a foreigner with black hair and a sallow face was re - arranging before proceeding with them on [his]4710-a foreigner with black hair and a sallow face way . [They]4711-they were in the main reduced copies of ancient marbles , and comprised divinities of a very different character from those [the girl]4201-the girl was accustomed to see portrayed , among them being [a Venus of standard pattern]4713-a venus of standard pattern , [a Diana]4714-a diana , and , of the other sex , [Apollo]245-apollo , [Bacchus]246-bacchus , and [Mars]247-mars . Though the figures were many yards away from [her]174-sue the south - west sun brought them out so brilliantly against the green herbage that [she]174-sue could discern their contours with luminous distinctness ; and being almost in a line between [herself]174-sue and [the church towers of [the city]414-the city]4715-the church towers of the city [they]4711-they awoke in [her]174-sue an oddly foreign and contrasting set of ideas by comparison . [The man]607-the man rose , and , seeing [her]174-sue , politely took off [his]607-the man cap , and cried "[0-i] [I]0-i - [i]0-i - [i]0-i - [mages]1175-mages ! " in an accent that agreed with [his]607-the man appearance . In a moment [he]607-the man dexterously lifted upon [his]607-the man knee the great board with its assembled notabilities divine and human , and raised it to the top of [his]607-the man head , bringing them on to [her]174-sue and resting the board on the stile . First [he]607-the man offered [her]174-sue [his]607-the man smaller wares - the busts of [kings]4718-kings and [queens]4719-queens , then [a minstrel]4720-a minstrel , then a winged Cupid . [She]174-sue shook [her]174-sue head . "[0-i] How much are these two ? " [she]174-sue said , touching with [her]174-sue finger the Venus and the Apollo - the largest figures on the tray . [He]607-the man said [she]174-sue should have them for ten shillings . "[0-i] [I]0-i can not afford that , " said [Sue]174-sue . [She]174-sue offered considerably less , and to [her]174-sue surprise [the image - man]4721-the image - man drew them from [their]4722-their wire stay and handed them over the stile . [She]174-sue clasped them as treasures . When they were paid for , and [the man]607-the man had gone , [she]174-sue began to be concerned as to what [she]174-sue should do with [them]4722-their . They seemed so very large now that they were in [her]174-sue possession , and so very naked . Being of a nervous temperament [she]174-sue trembled at [her]174-sue enterprise . When [she]174-sue handled them the white pipeclay came off on [her]174-sue gloves and jacket . After carrying them along a little way openly an idea came to [her]174-sue , and , pulling some huge burdock leaves , parsley , and other rank growths from the hedge , [she]174-sue wrapped up [her]174-sue burden as well as [she]174-sue could in these , so that what [she]174-sue carried appeared to be an enormous armful of green stuff gathered by [a zealous lover of nature]4724-a zealous lover of nature . "[0-i] Well , anything is better than those everlasting church fallals ! " [she]174-sue said . But [she]174-sue was still in a trembling state , and seemed almost to wish [she]174-sue had not bought the figures .
