" These little obstacles to the indulgence of what had been the merest passing fancy created in [Sue]174-sue a great zest for unpacking [her]174-sue objects and looking at them ; and at bedtime , when [she]174-sue was sure of being undisturbed , [she]174-sue unrobed the divinities in comfort . Placing the pair of figures on the chest of drawers , a candle on each side of [them]1180-two saints , [she]249-miss fontover withdrew to the bed , flung [herself]249-miss fontover down thereon , and began reading a book [she]249-miss fontover had taken from [her]249-miss fontover box , which [Miss Fontover]249-miss fontover knew nothing of . It was a volume of [Gibbon]254-gibbon , and [she]249-miss fontover read the chapter dealing with the reign of [Julian the Apostate]255-julian the apostate . Occasionally [she]249-miss fontover looked up at the statuettes , which appeared strange and out of place , there happening to be a Calvary print hanging between them , and , as if the scene suggested the action , [she]249-miss fontover at length jumped up and withdrew another book from [her]249-miss fontover box - a volume of verse - and turned to the familiar poem - [Thou]4745-thou hast conquered , [O pale Galilean]4746-o pale galilean : [The world]706-the world has grown grey from [thy]4745-thou breath ! which [she]249-miss fontover read to the end . Presently [she]249-miss fontover put out the candles , undressed , and finally extinguished [her]249-miss fontover own light . [She]249-miss fontover was of an age which usually sleeps soundly , yet to - night [she]249-miss fontover kept waking up , and every time [she]249-miss fontover opened [her]249-miss fontover eyes there was enough diffused light from [the street]4748-the street to show [her]249-miss fontover the white plaster figures , standing on the chest of drawers in odd contrast to [their]4749-their environment of text and martyr , and the Gothic - framed Crucifix - picture that was only discernible now as a Latin cross , the figure thereon being obscured by the shades . On one of these occasions the church clocks struck some small hour . It fell upon the ears of [another person who sat bending over [his]4750-another person who sat bending over his books at a not very distant spot in the same city books at [a not very distant spot in [the same city]4752-the same city]4751-a not very distant spot in the same city]4750-another person who sat bending over his books at a not very distant spot in the same city . Being Saturday night the morrow was one on which [Jude]180-jude had not set [his]180-jude alarm - clock to call [him]180-jude at [his]180-jude usually early time , and hence [he]180-jude had stayed up , as was [his]180-jude custom , two or three hours later than [he]180-jude could afford to do on any other day of the week . Just then [he]180-jude was earnestly reading from [his]180-jude [Griesbach]201-griesbach 's text . At the very time that [Sue]174-sue was tossing and staring at [her]174-sue figures , [the policeman]4108-the policeman and [belated citizens passing along under]4754-belated citizens passing along under [his]180-jude window might have heard , if [they]4749-their had stood still , strange syllables mumbled with fervour within - words that had for [Jude]180-jude an indescribable enchantment : inexplicable sounds something like these : - "[253-st. mary magdalen] All hemin heis Theos ho Pater , ex hou ta panta , kai hemeis eis auton : " Till the sounds rolled with reverent loudness , as a book was heard to close : - "[253-st. mary magdalen] Kai heis Kurios Iesous Christos , di hou ta panta kai hemeis di autou ! " IV [He]180-jude was [a handy man at [his]180-jude trade]4755-a handy man at his trade , [an all - round man]4756-an all - round man , as artizans in [country - towns]4757-country - towns are apt to be . In [London]7-london [the man who carves the boss]4758-the man who carves the boss or knob of leafage declines to cut the fragment of moulding which merges in that leafage , as if it were a degradation to do the second half of one whole . When there was not much Gothic moulding for [Jude]180-jude to run , or much window - tracery on the bankers , [he]180-jude would go out lettering monuments or tombstones , and take a pleasure in the change of handiwork . The next time that [he]180-jude saw [her]174-sue was when [he]180-jude was on a ladder executing a job of this sort inside [one of [the churches]4760-the churches]4759-one of the churches . There was a short morning service , and when [the parson]4761-the parson entered [Jude]180-jude came down from [his]180-jude ladder , and sat with [the half - dozen people forming the congregation]4762-the half - dozen people forming the congregation , till the prayer should be ended , and [he]180-jude could resume [his]180-jude tapping . [He]180-jude did not observe till the service was half over that [one of [the women]4764-the women]4763-one of the women was [Sue]174-sue , who had perforce accompanied the elderly [Miss Fontover thither]249-miss fontover . [Jude]180-jude sat watching [her]174-sue pretty shoulders , [her]174-sue easy , curiously nonchalant risings and sittings , and [her]174-sue perfunctory genuflexions , and thought what a help [such an Anglican]4765-such an anglican would have been to [him]180-jude in happier circumstances . It was not so much [his]180-jude anxiety to get on with [his]180-jude work that made [him]180-jude go up to it immediately [the worshipers]4766-the worshipers began to take [their]4766-the worshipers leave : it was that [he]180-jude dared not , in [this holy spot]4767-this holy spot , confront [the woman who was beginning to influence [him]180-jude in such an indescribable manner]4768-the woman who was beginning to influence him in such an indescribable manner . Those three enormous reasons why [he]180-jude must not attempt intimate acquaintance with [Sue Bridehead]174-sue , now that [his]180-jude interest in [her]174-sue had shown itself to be unmistakably of a sexual kind , loomed as stubbornly as ever . But it was also obvious that [man]575-man could not live by work alone ; that [the particular man]4770-the particular man [Jude]180-jude , at any rate , wanted something to love . [Some men]4527-some men would have rushed incontinently to [her]174-sue , snatched the pleasure of easy friendship which [she]174-sue could hardly refuse , and have left the rest to chance . Not so [Jude]180-jude - at first . But as the days , and still more particularly the lonely evenings , dragged along , [he]180-jude found [himself]180-jude , to [his]180-jude moral consternation , to be thinking more of [her]174-sue instead of thinking less of [her]174-sue , and experiencing a fearful bliss in doing what was erratic , informal , and unexpected . Surrounded by [her]174-sue influence all day , walking past [the spots [she]174-sue frequented]4772-the spots she frequented , [he]180-jude was always thinking of [her]174-sue , and was obliged to own to [himself]180-jude that [his]180-jude conscience was likely to be the loser in this battle . To be sure [she]174-sue was almost an ideality to [him]180-jude still . Perhaps to know [her]174-sue would be to cure [himself]180-jude of this unexpected and unauthorized passion . A voice whispered that , though [he]180-jude desired to know [her]174-sue , [he]180-jude did not desire to be cured . There was not the least doubt that from [his]180-jude own orthodox point of view the situation was growing immoral . For [Sue]174-sue to be [the loved one of [a man who was licensed by the laws of [his]180-jude country]4774-a man who was licensed by the laws of his country to love [Arabella]305-arabella and none other unto [his]180-jude life 's end]4773-the loved one of a man who was licensed by the laws of his country to love arabella and none other unto his life 's end , was a pretty bad second beginning when [the man]607-the man was bent on such a course as [Jude]180-jude purposed . This conviction was so real with [him]180-jude that one day when , as was frequent , [he]180-jude was at work in [a neighbouring village church]4776-a neighbouring village church alone , [he]180-jude felt it to be [his]180-jude duty to pray against [his]180-jude weakness . But much as [he]180-jude wished to be an exemplar in these things [he]180-jude could not get on . It was quite impossible , [he]180-jude found , to ask to be delivered from temptation when [your]4777-your heart 's desire was to be tempted unto seventy times seven . So [he]180-jude excused [himself]180-jude . "[253-st. mary magdalen] After all , " [he]180-jude said , "[253-st. mary magdalen] it is not altogether an erotolepsy that is the matter with [me]0-i , as at that first time . [I]0-i can see that [she]1181-she is exceptionally bright ; and it is partly a wish for intellectual sympathy , and a craving for loving - kindness in [my]0-i solitude . " Thus [he]180-jude went on adoring [her]1181-she , fearing to realize that it was human perversity . For whatever [Sue]174-sue 's virtues , talents , or ecclesiastical saturation , it was certain that those items were not at all the cause of [his]180-jude affection for [her]1181-she . On an afternoon at this time [a young girl]4778-a young girl entered [[the stone - mason]4615-the stone - mason 's yard]4616-the stone - mason 's yard with some hesitation , and , lifting [her]4778-a young girl skirts to avoid draggling them in the white dust , crossed towards [the office]4781-the office . "[1181-she] That 's [a nice girl]1182-a nice girl , " said [one of [the men known as [Uncle Joe]256-uncle joe]4783-the men known as uncle joe]4782-one of the men known as uncle joe . "[1182-a nice girl] Who is [she]1181-she ? " asked [another]4784-another . "[1181-she] [I]0-i do n't know - [I]0-i 've seen [her]1181-she about here and there . Why , yes , [she]1181-she 's [the daughter of [that clever chap Bridehead who did all the wrought ironwork at [St. Silas]45-st. silas ' ten years ago , and went away to [London]7-london afterwards]1184-that clever chap bridehead who did all the wrought ironwork at st. silas ' ten years ago , and went away to london afterwards]1183-the daughter of that clever chap bridehead who did all the wrought ironwork at st. silas ' ten years ago , and went away to london afterwards . " Meanwhile [the young woman]4785-the young woman had knocked at [the office]4781-the office door and asked if [Mr. Jude Fawley]180-jude was at work in [the yard]1139-the yard . It so happened that [Jude]180-jude had gone out somewhere or other that afternoon , which information [she]4785-the young woman received with a look of disappointment , and went away immediately . When [Jude]180-jude returned [they]4788-they told [him]180-jude , and described [her]174-sue , whereupon [he]180-jude exclaimed , "[1181-she] Why - that 's [[my]0-i cousin]1186-my cousin [Sue]174-sue ! " [He]180-jude looked along [the street]4748-the street after [her]174-sue , but [she]174-sue was out of sight . [He]180-jude had no longer any thought of a conscientious avoidance of [her]174-sue , and resolved to call upon [her]174-sue that very evening . And when [he]180-jude reached [[his]180-jude lodging]4560-his lodging [he]180-jude found a note from [her]174-sue - a first note - one of those documents which , simple and commonplace in themselves , are seen retrospectively to have been pregnant with impassioned consequences . The very unconsciousness of a looming drama which is shown in such innocent first epistles from [women]3879-women to [men]716-men , or vice versa , makes [them]4793-them , when such a drama follows , and they are read over by the purple or lurid light of it , all the more impressive , solemn , and in cases , terrible . [Sue]174-sue 's was of the most artless and natural kind . [She]174-sue addressed [him]180-jude as [[her]174-sue dear cousin]4794-her dear cousin [Jude]180-jude ; said [she]174-sue had only just learnt by the merest accident that [he]180-jude was living in [Christminster]180-jude , and reproached [him]180-jude with not letting [her]174-sue know . [They]4795-they might have had such nice times together , [she]174-sue said , for [she]174-sue was thrown much upon [herself]174-sue , and had hardly [any congenial friend]4796-any congenial friend . But now there was every probability of [her]174-sue soon going away , so that the chance of companionship would be lost perhaps for ever . A cold sweat overspread [Jude]180-jude at the news that [she]174-sue was going away . That was a contingency [he]180-jude had never thought of , and it spurred [him]180-jude to write all the more quickly to [her]174-sue . [He]180-jude would meet [her]174-sue that very evening , [he]180-jude said , one hour from the time of writing , at the cross in the pavement which marked the spot of the Martyrdoms . When [he]180-jude had despatched the note by [a boy]4566-a boy [he]180-jude regretted that in [his]180-jude hurry [he]180-jude should have suggested to [her]174-sue to meet [him]180-jude out of doors , when [he]180-jude might have said [he]180-jude would call upon [her]174-sue . It was , in fact , the country custom to meet thus , and nothing else had occurred to [him]180-jude . [Arabella]305-arabella had been met in the same way , unfortunately , and it might not seem respectable to [a dear girl like [Sue]174-sue]4798-a dear girl like sue . However , it could not be helped now , and [he]180-jude moved towards the point a few minutes before the hour , under the glimmer of the newly lighted lamps . [The broad street]4799-the broad street was silent , and almost deserted , although it was not late . [He]180-jude saw a figure on the other side , which turned out to be [hers]174-sue , and [they]4800-they both converged towards the crossmark at the same moment . " The voice , though positive and silvery , had been tremulous . [V]194-v [The schoolmaster]409-the schoolmaster sat in [[his]409-the schoolmaster homely dwelling attached to [the school]458-the school]4845-his homely dwelling attached to the school , both being modern erections ; and [he]409-the schoolmaster looked across the way at [the old house in which [[his]409-the schoolmaster teacher]4848-his teacher [Sue]174-sue had [a lodging]1024-a lodging]4847-the old house in which his teacher sue had a lodging . [A pupil - teacher who was to have been transferred to [[Mr. Phillotson]163-phillotson 's school]4851-mr. phillotson 's school]4850-a pupil - teacher who was to have been transferred to mr. phillotson 's school had failed [him]409-the schoolmaster , and [Sue]174-sue had been taken as stop - gap . All such provisional arrangements as these could only last till the next annual visit of [H.M. Inspector]4852-h.m. inspector , whose approval was necessary to make [them]4853-them permanent . Having taught for some two years in [London]7-london , though [she]174-sue had abandoned that vocation of late , [Miss Bridehead]251-miss bridehead was not exactly [a novice]4854-a novice , and [Phillotson]163-phillotson thought there would be no difficulty in retaining [her]174-sue services , which [he]163-phillotson already wished to do , though [she]174-sue had only been with [him]163-phillotson three or four weeks . It was a little over half - past eight o'clock in the morning and [he]163-phillotson was waiting to see [her]174-sue cross [the road]629-the road to [the school]458-the school , when [he]163-phillotson would follow . At twenty minutes to nine [she]174-sue did cross , a light hat tossed on [her]174-sue head ; and [he]163-phillotson watched [her]174-sue as a curiosity . A new emanation , which had nothing to do with [her]174-sue skill as [a teacher]4859-a teacher , seemed to surround [her]174-sue this morning . [He]163-phillotson went to [the school]458-the school also , and [Sue]174-sue remained governing [her]174-sue class at [the other end of [the room]4227-the room]4861-the other end of the room , all day under [his]163-phillotson eye . [She]174-sue certainly was [an excellent teacher]4863-an excellent teacher . It was part of [his]163-phillotson duty to give [her]174-sue private lessons in the evening , and some article in the Code made it necessary that [a respectable , elderly woman]4864-a respectable , elderly woman should be present at these lessons when [the teacher]4865-the teacher and [the taught]4866-the taught were of different sexes . [Richard Phillotson]258-phillotson thought of the absurdity of the regulation in this case , when [he]163-phillotson was old enough to be [[the girl]4201-the girl 's father]4868-the girl 's father ; but [he]163-phillotson faithfully acted up to it ; and sat down with [her]174-sue in [a room where [Mrs. Hawes]260-mrs. hawes , the widow at whose house [Sue]174-sue lodged]4869-a room where mrs. hawes , the widow at whose house sue lodged , occupied [herself]260-mrs. hawes with sewing . The regulation was , indeed , not easy to evade , for there was [no other sitting - room in [the dwelling]4871-the dwelling]4870-no other sitting - room in the dwelling . Sometimes as [she]174-sue figured - it was arithmetic that [they]4872-they were working at - [she]174-sue would involuntarily glance up with a little inquiring smile at [him]163-phillotson , as if [she]174-sue assumed that , being [the master]421-the master , [he]163-phillotson must perceive all that was passing in [her]174-sue brain , as right or wrong . [Phillotson]258-phillotson was not really thinking of the arithmetic at all , but of [her]174-sue , in a novel way which somehow seemed strange to [him]163-phillotson as [preceptor]4874-preceptor . Perhaps [she]174-sue knew that [he]163-phillotson was thinking of [her]174-sue thus . For a few weeks [their]4872-they work had gone on with a monotony which in itself was a delight to [him]163-phillotson . Then it happened that [the children]4875-the children were to be taken to [Christminster]180-jude to see an itinerant exhibition , in the shape of a model of [Jerusalem]50-jerusalem , to which [schools]4876-schools were admitted at a penny a head in the interests of education . [They]4872-they marched along [the road]629-the road two and two , [she]174-sue beside [her]174-sue class with [her]174-sue simple cotton sunshade , [her]174-sue little thumb cocked up against its stem ; and [Phillotson]258-phillotson behind in [his]163-phillotson long dangling coat , handling [his]163-phillotson walking - stick genteelly , in the musing mood which had come over [him]163-phillotson since [her]174-sue arrival . The afternoon was one of sun and dust , and when [they]4872-they entered [the exhibition room]4878-the exhibition room [few people]4879-few people were present but [themselves]4879-few people . The model of [the ancient city]4880-the ancient city stood in the middle of [the apartment]4881-the apartment , and [the proprietor]4882-the proprietor , with a fine religious philanthropy written on [his]4882-the proprietor features , walked round [it]4880-the ancient city with a pointer in [his]4882-the proprietor hand , showing [the young people]4883-the young people [the various quarters and places known to [them]4883-the young people by name from reading [their]4883-the young people Bibles]4884-the various quarters and places known to them by name from reading their bibles ; [Mount Moriah]51-mount moriah , [the Valley of [Jehoshaphat]52-jehoshaphat]4885-the valley of jehoshaphat , [the City of Zion]4886-the city of zion , the walls and the gates , outside one of which there was a large mound like a tumulus , and on the mound a little white cross . The spot , [he]4882-the proprietor said , was [Calvary]53-calvary . "[1208-your cousin] [I]0-i think , " said [Sue]174-sue to [the schoolmaster]409-the schoolmaster , as [she]0-i stood with [him]409-the schoolmaster a little in the background , "[1208-your cousin] that this model , elaborate as it is , is a very imaginary production . How does [anybody]4107-anybody know that [Jerusalem]50-jerusalem was like this in the time of [Christ]261-christ ? [I]0-i am sure [this man]4146-this man does n't . " "[4146-this man] It is made after the best conjectural maps , based on actual visits to [the city]414-the city as [it]414-the city now exists . " "[4146-this man] [I]0-i fancy [we]1231-we have had enough of [Jerusalem]50-jerusalem , " [she]0-i said , "[0-i] considering [we]1231-we are not descended from [the Jews]262-the jews . There was nothing first - rate about [the place]3987-the place , or [people]658-people , after all - as there was about [Athens]54-athens , [Rome]37-rome , [Alexandria]55-alexandria , and [other old cities]1234-other old cities . " "[4146-this man] But [[my]0-i dear girl]1235-my dear girl , consider what it is to [us]1231-we ! " [She]0-i was silent , for [she]0-i was easily repressed ; and then perceived behind the group of [children clustered round the model]4888-children clustered round the model [a young man in a white flannel jacket]4889-a young man in a white flannel jacket , [his]180-jude form being bent so low in [his]180-jude intent inspection of [the Valley of [Jehoshaphat]52-jehoshaphat]4885-the valley of jehoshaphat that [his]180-jude face was almost hidden from view by [the Mount of Olives]56-the mount of olives . "[4146-this man] Look at [[your]1235-my dear girl cousin]1208-your cousin [Jude]180-jude , " continued [the schoolmaster]409-the schoolmaster . "[180-jude] [He]180-jude does n't think [we]1231-we have had enough of [Jerusalem]50-jerusalem ! " "[180-jude] Ah - [I]0-i did n't see [him]180-jude ! " [she]0-i cried in [her]0-i quick , light voice . "[180-jude] [Jude]180-jude - how seriously [you]180-jude are going into it ! " [Jude]180-jude started up from [his]180-jude reverie , and saw [her]0-i . "[174-sue] Oh - [Sue]174-sue ! " [he]180-jude said , with a glad flush of embarrassment . "[174-sue] These are [[your]174-sue school - [children]4054-children]1237-your school - children , of course ! [I]0-i saw that [schools]4876-schools were admitted in the afternoons , and thought [you]174-sue might come ; but [I]0-i got so deeply interested that [I]0-i did n't remember where [I]0-i was . How it carries one back , does n't it ! [I]0-i could examine it for hours , but [I]0-i have only a few minutes , unfortunately ; for [I]0-i am in the middle of a job out here . " "[174-sue] [[Your]174-sue cousin]1208-your cousin is so terribly clever that [she]1208-your cousin criticizes it unmercifully , " said [Phillotson]258-phillotson , with good - humoured satire . "[1208-your cousin] [She]1208-your cousin is quite sceptical as to its correctness . " "[1208-your cousin] No , [Mr. Phillotson]163-phillotson , [I]0-i am not - altogether ! " "[163-phillotson] That 's a good [Jude]180-jude - [I]0-i know [YOU]163-phillotson believe in [me]0-i ! " [She]174-sue impulsively seized [his]180-jude hand , and leaving a reproachful look on [the schoolmaster]409-the schoolmaster turned away to [Jude]180-jude , [her]174-sue voice revealing a tremor which [she]174-sue [herself]174-sue felt to be absurdly uncalled for by sarcasm so gentle . [She]174-sue had not the least conception how the hearts of [the twain]4893-the twain went out to [her]174-sue at this momentary revelation of feeling , and what a complication [she]174-sue was building up thereby in the futures of both . [The model]4894-the model wore too much of an educational aspect for [the children]4875-the children not to tire of it soon , and a little later in the afternoon [they]4875-the children were all marched back to [Lumsdon]46-lumsdon , [Jude]180-jude returning to [his]180-jude work . [He]180-jude watched [the juvenile flock]4896-the juvenile flock in [their]4896-the juvenile flock clean frocks and pinafores , filing down [the street]4748-the street towards [the country beside [Phillotson]163-phillotson and [Sue]174-sue]4898-the country beside phillotson and sue , and a sad , dissatisfied sense of being out of the scheme of [the latters]4899-the latters ' lives had possession of [him]180-jude . [Phillotson]163-phillotson had invited [him]180-jude to walk out and see [them]4875-the children on Friday evening , when there would be no lessons to give to [Sue]174-sue , and [Jude]180-jude had eagerly promised to avail [himself]180-jude of the opportunity . " [[Her]0-i Majesty 's school - inspector]4903-her majesty 's school - inspector was at that time paying ' surprise - visits "[0-i] in [this neighbourhood]1244-this neighbourhood to test the teaching unawares ; and two days later , in the middle of the morning lessons , the latch of the door was softly lifted , and in walked [[my]0-i gentleman]1245-my gentleman , [the king of terrors]1246-the king of terrors - to [[pupil]1247-pupil - [teachers]4901-teachers]1248-pupil - teachers . To [Mr. Phillotson]163-phillotson the surprise was not great ; like [the lady in the story]1250-the lady in the story [he]163-phillotson had been played that trick too many times to be unprepared . But [Sue]174-sue 's class was at the further end of [the room]4227-the room , and [her]174-sue back was towards the entrance ; [the inspector]1252-the inspector therefore came and stood behind [her]174-sue and watched [her]174-sue teaching some half - minute before [she]174-sue became aware of [his]1252-the inspector presence . [She]174-sue turned , and realized that an oft - dreaded moment had come . The effect upon [her]174-sue timidity was such that [she]174-sue uttered a cry of fright . [Phillotson]163-phillotson , with a strange instinct of solicitude quite beyond [his]163-phillotson control , was at [her]174-sue side just in time to prevent [her]174-sue falling from faintness . [She]174-sue soon recovered [herself]174-sue , and laughed ; but when [the inspector]1252-the inspector had gone there was a reaction , and [she]174-sue was so white that [Phillotson]163-phillotson took [her]174-sue into [[his]163-phillotson room]4314-his room , and gave [her]174-sue some brandy to bring [her]174-sue round . [She]174-sue found [him]163-phillotson holding [her]174-sue hand . " [You]163-phillotson ought to have told [me]174-sue , "[174-sue] [she]174-sue gasped petulantly , " that one of [the inspector]1252-the inspector 's surprise - visits was imminent ! "[174-sue] " [He]1252-the inspector wo n't do that , [[my]163-phillotson dear little girl]4906-my dear little girl . "[163-phillotson] [He]163-phillotson looked so gently at [her]174-sue that [she]174-sue was moved , and regretted that [she]174-sue had upbraided [him]163-phillotson . When [she]174-sue was better [she]174-sue went [home]3897-home . [Jude]180-jude in the meantime had been waiting impatiently for [Friday]263-friday . On both Wednesday and Thursday [he]180-jude had been so much under the influence of [his]180-jude desire to see [her]174-sue that [he]180-jude walked after dark some distance along [the road]629-the road in the direction of [the village]410-the village , and , on returning to [[his]180-jude room]4314-his room to read , found [himself]180-jude quite unable to concentrate [his]180-jude mind on the page . On Friday , as soon as [he]180-jude had got [himself]180-jude up as [he]180-jude thought [Sue]174-sue would like to see [him]180-jude , and made a hasty tea , [he]180-jude set out , notwithstanding that the evening was wet . The trees overhead deepened the gloom of the hour , and they dripped sadly upon [him]180-jude , impressing [him]180-jude with forebodings - illogical forebodings ; for though [he]180-jude knew that [he]180-jude loved [her]174-sue [he]180-jude also knew that [he]180-jude could not be more to [her]174-sue than [he]180-jude was . On turning the corner and entering [the village]410-the village the first sight that greeted [his]180-jude eyes was that of [two figures under one umbrella]1260-two figures under one umbrella coming out of the vicarage gate . [He]180-jude was too far back for [them]1260-two figures under one umbrella to notice [him]180-jude , but [he]180-jude knew in a moment that [they]1260-two figures under one umbrella were [Sue]174-sue and [Phillotson]163-phillotson . [The latter]444-the latter was holding the umbrella over [her]174-sue head , and [they]1260-two figures under one umbrella had evidently been paying a visit to [the vicar]1262-the vicar - probably on some business connected with the school work . And as [they]1260-two figures under one umbrella walked along [the wet and deserted lane]1263-the wet and deserted lane [Jude]180-jude saw [Phillotson]163-phillotson place [his]163-phillotson arm round [the girl]4201-the girl 's waist ; whereupon [she]174-sue gently removed it ; but [he]163-phillotson replaced it ; and [she]174-sue let it remain , looking quickly round [her]174-sue with an air of misgiving . [She]174-sue did not look absolutely behind [her]174-sue , and therefore did not see [Jude]180-jude , who sank into the hedge like [one struck with a blight]1265-one struck with a blight . There [he]180-jude remained hidden till [they]1260-two figures under one umbrella had reached [[Sue]174-sue 's cottage]1266-sue 's cottage and [she]174-sue had passed in , [Phillotson]163-phillotson going on to [the school]458-the school hard by . " Oh , [he]180-jude 's too old for [her]174-sue - too old ! "[180-jude] cried [Jude]180-jude in all the terrible sickness of hopeless , handicapped love . [He]180-jude could not interfere . Was [he]180-jude not [Arabella]305-arabella 's ? [He]180-jude was unable to go on further , and retraced [his]180-jude steps towards [Christminster]180-jude . Every tread of [his]180-jude feet seemed to say to [him]180-jude that [he]180-jude must on no account stand in [the schoolmaster]409-the schoolmaster 's way with [Sue]174-sue . [Phillotson]163-phillotson was perhaps twenty years [her]174-sue senior , but many a happy marriage had been made in such conditions of age . The ironical clinch to [his]180-jude sorrow was given by the thought that the intimacy between [[his]180-jude cousin]3917-his cousin and [the schoolmaster]409-the schoolmaster had been brought about entirely by [himself]180-jude . [[VI Jude]180-jude 's old and embittered aunt]1271-vi jude 's old and embittered aunt lay unwell at [Marygreen]1-marygreen , and on the following Sunday [he]180-jude went to see [her]1271-vi jude 's old and embittered aunt - a visit which was the result of a victorious struggle against [his]180-jude inclination to turn aside to [the village of Lumsdon]1272-the village of lumsdon and obtain a miserable interview with [[his]180-jude cousin]3917-his cousin , in which the word nearest [his]180-jude heart could not be spoken , and the sight which had tortured [him]180-jude could not be revealed . [[His]180-jude aunt]555-his aunt was now unable to leave [her]555-his aunt bed , and a great part of [Jude]180-jude 's short day was occupied in making arrangements for [her]555-his aunt comfort . "[1292-the sick woman] [The neighbour]1293-the neighbour told also of [Sue]174-sue 's accomplishments in other kinds : " [She]174-sue was not exactly [a tomboy]4930-a tomboy , [you]4928-you know ; but [she]174-sue could do things that only [boys]4931-boys do , as a rule . "[180-jude] Still , the remark was sufficient to withdraw [Jude]180-jude 's attention from the imaginative world [he]180-jude had lately inhabited , in which [an abstract figure]1301-an abstract figure , more or less [himself]180-jude , was steeping [his]180-jude mind in a sublimation of the arts and sciences , and making [his]180-jude calling and election sure to a seat in [the paradise of [the learned]1303-the learned]1302-the paradise of the learned . [He]180-jude was set regarding [his]180-jude prospects in a cold northern light . [He]180-jude had lately felt that [he]180-jude could not quite satisfy [himself]180-jude in [his]180-jude Greek - in the Greek of [the dramatists]1304-the dramatists particularly . So fatigued was [he]180-jude sometimes after [his]180-jude day 's work that [he]180-jude could not maintain the critical attention necessary for thorough application . [He]180-jude felt that [he]180-jude wanted [a coach]1305-a coach - [a friend at [his]180-jude elbow]1306-a friend at his elbow to tell [him]180-jude in a moment what sometimes would occupy [him]180-jude a weary month in extracting from unanticipative , clumsy books . It was decidedly necessary to consider facts a little more closely than [he]180-jude had done of late . What was the good , after all , of using up [his]180-jude spare hours in a vague labour called " private study "[180-jude] without giving an outlook on practicabilities ? " [I]180-jude ought to have thought of this before , "[180-jude] [he]180-jude said , as [he]180-jude journeyed back . " It would have been better never to have embarked in the scheme at all than to do it without seeing clearly where [I]180-jude am going , or what [I]180-jude am aiming at ... This hovering outside the walls of [the colleges]727-the colleges , as if expecting some arm to be stretched out from [them]727-the colleges to lift [me]180-jude inside , wo n't do ! [I]180-jude must get special information . "[180-jude] The next week accordingly [he]180-jude sought it . What at first seemed an opportunity occurred one afternoon when [he]180-jude saw [an elderly gentleman]1307-an elderly gentleman , who had been pointed out as the head of [a particular college]1308-a particular college , walking in the public path of [a parklike enclosure near the spot at which [Jude]180-jude chanced to be sitting]1309-a parklike enclosure near the spot at which jude chanced to be sitting . [The gentleman]1310-the gentleman came nearer , and [Jude]180-jude looked anxiously at [his]1310-the gentleman face . It seemed benign , considerate , yet rather reserved . On second thoughts [Jude]180-jude felt that [he]180-jude could not go up and address [him]1310-the gentleman ; but [he]180-jude was sufficiently influenced by the incident to think what a wise thing it would be for [him]180-jude to state [his]180-jude difficulties by letter to [some of the best and most judicious of [these old masters]1312-these old masters]1311-some of the best and most judicious of these old masters , and obtain [their]1311-some of the best and most judicious of these old masters advice . During the next week or two [he]180-jude accordingly placed [himself]180-jude in such positions about [the city]414-the city as would afford [him]180-jude glimpses of [several of the most distinguished among [the provosts]1315-the provosts]1314-several of the most distinguished among the provosts , [wardens]1316-wardens , and [other heads of [houses]1318-houses]1317-other heads of houses ; and from those [he]180-jude ultimately selected five whose physiognomies seemed to say to [him]180-jude that [they]1311-some of the best and most judicious of these old masters were [appreciative and far - seeing men]1319-appreciative and far - seeing men . To these five [he]180-jude addressed letters , briefly stating [his]180-jude difficulties , and asking [their]1311-some of the best and most judicious of these old masters opinion on [his]180-jude stranded situation . When the letters were posted [Jude]180-jude mentally began to criticize [them]1311-some of the best and most judicious of these old masters ; [he]180-jude wished they had not been sent . " It is just one of those intrusive , vulgar , pushing , applications which are so common in these days , "[180-jude] [he]180-jude thought . " Why could n't [I]180-jude know better than address [utter strangers]4954-utter strangers in such a way ? [I]180-jude may be [an impostor]4955-an impostor , [an idle scamp]4956-an idle scamp , [a man with a bad character]4957-a man with a bad character , for all that [they]4954-utter strangers know to the contrary ... Perhaps that 's what [I]180-jude am ! "[180-jude] Nevertheless , [he]180-jude found [himself]180-jude clinging to the hope of some reply as to [his]180-jude one last chance of redemption . [He]180-jude waited day after day , saying that it was perfectly absurd to expect , yet expecting . While [he]180-jude waited [he]180-jude was suddenly stirred by news about [Phillotson]163-phillotson . [Phillotson]163-phillotson was giving up [the school near [Christminster]180-jude]1320-the school near christminster , for [a larger one further south , in [Mid - Wessex]58-mid - wessex]1321-a larger one further south , in mid - wessex . What this meant ; how it would affect [[his]163-phillotson cousin]3917-his cousin ; whether , as seemed possible , it was a practical move of [the schoolmaster]409-the schoolmaster 's towards a larger income , in view of a provision for two instead of one , [he]180-jude would not allow [himself]180-jude to say . And the tender relations between [Phillotson]163-phillotson and [the young girl of whom [Jude]180-jude]1324-the young girl of whom jude was passionately enamoured effectually made it repugnant to [Jude]180-jude 's tastes to apply to [Phillotson]163-phillotson for advice on [his]163-phillotson own scheme . Meanwhile [the academic dignitaries to whom [Jude]180-jude]1325-the academic dignitaries to whom jude had written vouchsafed no answer , and [the young man]4185-the young man was thus thrown back entirely on [himself]4185-the young man , as formerly , with the added gloom of a weakened hope . By indirect inquiries [he]180-jude soon perceived clearly what [he]180-jude had long uneasily suspected , that to qualify [himself]180-jude for certain open scholarships and exhibitions was the only brilliant course . But to do this a good deal of coaching would be necessary , and much natural ability . It was next to impossible that [a man reading on [his]180-jude own system]1327-a man reading on his own system , however widely and thoroughly , even over the prolonged period of ten years , should be able to compete with those who had passed [their]1328-their lives under [trained teachers and had worked to ordained lines]1329-trained teachers and had worked to ordained lines . The other course , that of buying [himself]180-jude in , so to speak , seemed the only one really open to [men like [him]180-jude]1330-men like him , the difficulty being simply of a material kind . With the help of [his]180-jude information [he]180-jude began to reckon the extent of this material obstacle , and ascertained , to [his]180-jude dismay , that , at the rate at which , with the best of fortune , [he]180-jude would be able to save money , fifteen years must elapse before [he]180-jude could be in a position to forward testimonials to the head of [a college]1030-a college and advance to a matriculation examination . The undertaking was hopeless . [He]180-jude saw what a curious and cunning glamour [the neighbourhood of [the place]3987-the place]1332-the neighbourhood of the place had exercised over [him]180-jude . To get [there]3887-there and live [there]3887-there , to move among [the churches and halls]1336-the churches and halls and become imbued with the genius loci , had seemed to [[his]180-jude dreaming youth]1337-his dreaming youth , as the spot shaped its charms to [him]180-jude from its halo on the horizon , the obvious and ideal thing to do . " Let [me]180-jude only get [there]3887-there , "[180-jude] [he]180-jude had said with the fatuousness of Crusoe over [[his]180-jude big boat]1338-his big boat , " and the rest is but a matter of time and energy . "[180-jude] It would have been far better for [him]180-jude in every way if [he]180-jude had never come within sight and sound of [the delusive precincts]1339-the delusive precincts , had gone to [some busy commercial town]1340-some busy commercial town with the sole object of making money by [his]180-jude wits , and thence surveyed [his]180-jude plan in true perspective . Well , all that was clear to [him]180-jude amounted to this , that the whole scheme had burst up , like an iridescent soap - bubble , under the touch of a reasoned inquiry . [He]180-jude looked back at [himself]180-jude along the vista of [his]180-jude past years , and [his]180-jude thought was akin to [Heine]268-heine 's : Above [the youth]1341-the youth 's inspired and flashing eyes [I]0-i see [the motley mocking fool's - cap rise]1342-the motley mocking fool's - cap rise ! Fortunately [he]180-jude had not been allowed to bring [his]180-jude disappointment into [his]180-jude dear [Sue]174-sue 's life by involving [her]174-sue in this collapse . And the painful details of [his]180-jude awakening to a sense of [his]180-jude limitations should now be spared [her]174-sue as far as possible . After all , [she]174-sue had only known a little part of the miserable struggle in which [he]180-jude had been engaged thus unequipped , poor , and unforeseeing . [He]180-jude always remembered the appearance of the afternoon on which [he]180-jude awoke from [his]180-jude dream . Not quite knowing what to do with [himself]180-jude , [he]180-jude went up to [an octagonal chamber in the lantern of [a singularly built theatre that was set amidst [this quaint and singular city]1345-this quaint and singular city]1344-a singularly built theatre that was set amidst this quaint and singular city]1343-an octagonal chamber in the lantern of a singularly built theatre that was set amidst this quaint and singular city . [It]1343-an octagonal chamber in the lantern of a singularly built theatre that was set amidst this quaint and singular city had windows all round , from which an outlook over [the whole town]1346-the whole town and [its]1346-the whole town edifices could be gained . [Jude]180-jude 's eyes swept all the views in succession , meditatively , mournfully , yet sturdily . [Those buildings]4606-those buildings and [their]4606-those buildings associations and privileges were not for [him]180-jude . From the looming roof of [the great library]1348-the great library , into which [he]180-jude hardly ever had time to enter , [his]180-jude gaze travelled on to the varied spires , [halls]4010-halls , [gables]1350-gables , [streets]1351-streets , [chapels]1352-chapels , [gardens]1353-gardens , quadrangles , which composed the ensemble of this unrivalled panorama . [He]180-jude saw that [his]180-jude destiny lay not with these , but among the manual toilers in [the shabby purlieu which [he]180-jude [himself]180-jude occupied]1354-the shabby purlieu which he himself occupied , unrecognized as part of [the city]414-the city at all by [its visitors]1356-its visitors and [panegyrists]1357-panegyrists , yet without whose denizens [the hard readers]1358-the hard readers could not read nor [the high thinkers]1359-the high thinkers live . [He]180-jude looked over [the town]4154-the town into [the country beyond]1361-the country beyond , to the trees which screened [her]1362-her whose presence had at first been the support of [his]180-jude heart , and whose loss was now a maddening torture . But for this blow [he]180-jude might have borne with [his]180-jude fate . With [Sue]174-sue as companion [he]180-jude could have renounced [his]180-jude ambitions with a smile . Without [her]174-sue it was inevitable that the reaction from the long strain to which [he]180-jude had subjected [himself]180-jude should affect [him]180-jude disastrously . [Phillotson]163-phillotson had no doubt passed through a similar intellectual disappointment to that which now enveloped [him]180-jude . But [the schoolmaster]409-the schoolmaster had been since blest with the consolation of [sweet Sue]174-sue , while for [him]180-jude there was [no consoler]1364-no consoler . Descending to [the streets]680-the streets , [he]180-jude went listlessly along till [he]180-jude arrived at [an inn]1366-an inn , and entered [it]1366-an inn . Here [he]180-jude drank several glasses of beer in rapid succession , and when [he]180-jude came out it was night . By the light of the flickering lamps [he]180-jude rambled [home]3897-home to supper , and had not long been sitting at table when [[his]180-jude landlady]4617-his landlady brought up a letter that had just arrived for [him]180-jude . [She]4617-his landlady laid it down as if impressed with a sense of its possible importance , and on looking at it [Jude]180-jude perceived that it bore the embossed stamp of one of [the colleges whose heads [he]180-jude had addressed]1369-the colleges whose heads he had addressed . " ONE - at last ! "[180-jude] cried [Jude]180-jude . The communication was brief , and not exactly what [he]180-jude had expected ; though it really was from [the master in person]1370-the master in person . It ran thus : [BIBLIOLL COLLEGE]59-biblioll college . [SIR]3888-sir , - [I]0-i have read [your]3888-sir letter with interest ; and , judging from [your]3888-sir description of [yourself]3888-sir as [a working - man]1372-a working - man , [I]0-i venture to think that [you]3888-sir will have a much better chance of success in life by remaining in [your]3888-sir own sphere and sticking to [your]3888-sir trade than by adopting any other course . That , therefore , is what [I]0-i advise [you]3888-sir to do . [Yours]3888-sir faithfully , [T. TETUPHENAY]269-t. tetuphenay . To [Mr. J. FAWLEY]270-mr. fawley , [Stone - mason]1373-stone - mason . This terribly sensible advice exasperated [Jude]180-jude . [He]180-jude had known all that before . [He]180-jude knew it was true . Yet it seemed a hard slap after ten years of labour , and its effect upon [him]180-jude just now was to make [him]180-jude rise recklessly from the table , and , instead of reading as usual , to go [downstairs]4245-downstairs and into [the street]4748-the street . [He]180-jude stood at a bar and tossed off two or three glasses , then unconsciously sauntered along till [he]180-jude came to a spot called [The Fourways]60-the fourways in [the middle of [the city]414-the city]1376-the middle of the city , gazing abstractedly at [the groups of people like one in a trance]1378-the groups of people like one in a trance , till , coming to [himself]180-jude , [he]180-jude began talking to [the policeman fixed there]1379-the policeman fixed there . [That officer]1380-that officer yawned , stretched out [his]1380-that officer elbows , elevated [himself]1380-that officer an inch and a half on the balls of [his]1380-that officer toes , smiled , and looking humorously at [Jude]180-jude , said , " [You]180-jude 've had a wet , [young man]3930-young man . "[1380-that officer] " No ; [I]180-jude 've only begun , "[180-jude] [he]180-jude replied cynically . Whatever [his]180-jude wetness , [his]180-jude brains were dry enough . [He]180-jude only heard in part [the policeman]4108-the policeman 's further remarks , having fallen into thought on what [struggling people like [himself]180-jude had stood at [that crossway]1383-that crossway , whom [nobody]4069-nobody ever thought of now]1382-struggling people like himself had stood at that crossway , whom nobody ever thought of now . [It]1383-that crossway had more history than [the oldest college in [the city]414-the city]1385-the oldest college in the city . [It]1383-that crossway was literally teeming , stratified , with the shades of [human groups , who had met there for tragedy , comedy , farce ; real enactments of the intensest kind]1387-human groups , who had met there for tragedy , comedy , farce ; real enactments of the intensest kind . At [Fourways men]1388-fourways men had stood and talked of [Napoleon]271-napoleon , the loss of [America]61-america , the execution of [King Charles]272-king charles , the burning of [the Martyrs]1389-the martyrs , the Crusades , the Norman Conquest , possibly of the arrival of [Caesar]195-caesar . Here [the two sexes]1390-the two sexes had met for loving , hating , coupling , parting ; had waited , had suffered , for [each other]4188-each other ; had triumphed over [each other]4188-each other ; cursed [each other]4188-each other in jealousy , blessed [each other]4188-each other in forgiveness . [He]180-jude began to see that [the town]4154-the town life was a book of humanity infinitely more palpitating , varied , and compendious than the gown life . [These struggling men]1396-these struggling men and women before [him]180-jude were the reality of [Christminster]180-jude , though [they]1396-these struggling men knew little of [Christ]261-christ or [Minster]1397-minster . That was one of the humours of things . [The floating population of [students]1399-students]1398-the floating population of students and [teachers , who did know both in a way]1400-teachers , who did know both in a way , were not [Christminster]180-jude in a local sense at all . [He]180-jude looked at [his]180-jude watch , and , in pursuit of this idea , [he]180-jude went on till [he]180-jude came to [a public hall]1401-a public hall , where [a promenade concert]1402-a promenade concert was in progress . [Jude]180-jude entered , and found [the room]4227-the room full of [shop youths]1404-shop youths and [girls]540-girls , [soldiers]1406-soldiers , [apprentices]1407-apprentices , [boys of eleven]1408-boys of eleven smoking cigarettes , and [light women of the more respectable and amateur class]1409-light women of the more respectable and amateur class . [He]180-jude had tapped the real Christminster life . [A band]1410-a band was playing , and [the crowd]1411-the crowd walked about and jostled [each other]4188-each other , and every now and then [a man]543-a man got upon a platform and sang a comic song . The spirit of [Sue]174-sue seemed to hover round [him]180-jude and prevent [his]180-jude flirting and drinking with the frolicsome girls who made advances - wistful to gain a little joy . At ten o'clock [he]180-jude came away , choosing a circuitous route homeward to pass the gates of [the college]4625-the college whose head had just sent [him]180-jude the note . The gates were shut , and , by an impulse , [he]180-jude took from [his]180-jude pocket the lump of chalk which as [a workman]1415-a workman [he]180-jude usually carried there , and wrote along the wall : " [I]180-jude have understanding as well as [you]4960-you ; [I]180-jude am not inferior to [you]4960-you : yea , who knoweth not such things as these ? "[180-jude] - Job xii . 3 . VII The stroke of scorn relieved [his]180-jude mind , and the next morning [he]180-jude laughed at [his]180-jude self - conceit . But the laugh was not a healthy one . [He]180-jude re - read the letter from [the master]421-the master , and the wisdom in its lines , which had at first exasperated [him]180-jude , chilled and depressed [him]180-jude now . [He]180-jude saw [himself]180-jude as [a fool]3943-a fool indeed . Deprived of the objects of both intellect and emotion , [he]180-jude could not proceed to [his]180-jude work . Whenever [he]180-jude felt reconciled to [his]180-jude fate as [a student]733-a student , there came to disturb [his]180-jude calm [his]180-jude hopeless relations with [Sue]174-sue . That [the one affined soul [he]180-jude had ever met]1419-the one affined soul he had ever met was lost to [him]180-jude through [his]180-jude marriage returned upon [him]180-jude with cruel persistency , till , unable to bear it longer , [he]180-jude again rushed for distraction to the real Christminster life . [He]180-jude now sought it out in [an obscure and low - ceiled tavern up a court which was well known to certain worthies of [the place]3987-the place]1420-an obscure and low - ceiled tavern up a court which was well known to certain worthies of the place , and in brighter times would have interested [him]180-jude simply by [its]1420-an obscure and low - ceiled tavern up a court which was well known to certain worthies of the place quaintness . Here [he]180-jude sat more or less all the day , convinced that [he]180-jude was at bottom [a vicious character , of whom it was hopeless to expect anything]1422-a vicious character , of whom it was hopeless to expect anything . In the evening [the frequenters of [the house]504-the house]1423-the frequenters of the house dropped in one by one , [Jude]180-jude still retaining [his]180-jude seat in the corner , though [his]180-jude money was all spent , and [he]180-jude had not eaten anything the whole day except a biscuit . [He]180-jude surveyed [[his]180-jude gathering companions]1425-his gathering companions with all the equanimity and philosophy of [a man who has been drinking long and slowly]1426-a man who has been drinking long and slowly , and made [friends]1427-friends with [several]1428-several : to wit , [Tinker Taylor]273-tinker taylor , [a decayed church - ironmonger who appeared to have been of a religious turn in earlier years]1429-a decayed church - ironmonger who appeared to have been of a religious turn in earlier years , but was somewhat blasphemous now ; also [a red - nosed auctioneer]1430-a red - nosed auctioneer ; also [two Gothic masons like [himself]180-jude]1431-two gothic masons like himself , called [Uncle Jim]274-uncle jim and [Uncle Joe]256-uncle joe . There were present , too , [some clerks]1432-some clerks , and [a gown-]1433-a gown- and [surplice - maker 's assistant]1434-surplice - maker 's assistant ; [two ladies who sported moral characters of various depths of shade]1435-two ladies who sported moral characters of various depths of shade , according to [[their]1435-two ladies who sported moral characters of various depths of shade company]1436-their company , nicknamed " [Bower o ' Bliss "[1435-two ladies who sported moral characters of various depths of shade] and " Freckles "]275-bower o ' bliss " and " freckles "[1435-two ladies who sported moral characters of various depths of shade] ; [some horsey men " in the know "[1437-some horsey men " in the know " of betting circles] of betting circles]1437-some horsey men " in the know " of betting circles ; [a travelling actor from the theatre]1438-a travelling actor from the theatre , and [two devil - may - care young men who proved to be gownless undergraduates]1439-two devil - may - care young men who proved to be gownless undergraduates ; [they]1435-two ladies who sported moral characters of various depths of shade had slipped in by stealth to meet [a man about bull - pups]1440-a man about bull - pups , and stayed to drink and smoke short pipes with [the racing gents aforesaid]1441-the racing gents aforesaid , looking at [their]1441-the racing gents aforesaid watches every now and then . The conversation waxed general . [Christminster society]1442-christminster society was criticized , [the dons]1443-the dons , [magistrates]1444-magistrates , and [other people in authority]1445-other people in authority being sincerely pitied for [their]1445-other people in authority shortcomings , while opinions on how [they]1445-other people in authority ought to conduct [themselves]1445-other people in authority and [their]1445-other people in authority affairs to be properly respected , were exchanged in a large - minded and disinterested manner . [Jude Fawley]180-jude , with the self - conceit , effrontery , and aplomb of [a strong - brained fellow in liquor]1446-a strong - brained fellow in liquor , threw in [his]180-jude remarks somewhat peremptorily ; and [his]180-jude aims having been what they were for so many years , everything [the others]762-the others said turned upon [his]180-jude tongue , by a sort of mechanical craze , to the subject of scholarship and study , the extent of [his]180-jude own learning being dwelt upon with an insistence that would have appeared pitiable to [himself]180-jude in [his]180-jude sane hours . " [I]180-jude do n't care a damn , "[180-jude] [he]180-jude was saying , " for [any provost]4961-any provost , [warden]4962-warden , [principal]4963-principal , [fellow]4964-fellow , or [cursed master of arts]4965-cursed master of arts in [the university]4966-the university ! What [I]180-jude know is that [I]180-jude 'd lick 'em on [their]762-the others own ground if [they]762-the others 'd give [me]180-jude a chance , and show ['em]762-the others a few things [they]762-the others are not up to yet ! "[180-jude] " Hear , hear ! "[1448-the undergraduates] said [the undergraduates]1448-the undergraduates from the corner , where [they]1448-the undergraduates were talking privately about [the pups]1449-the pups . " [You]273-tinker taylor always was fond o ' books , [I]273-tinker taylor 've heard , "[273-tinker taylor] said [Tinker Taylor]273-tinker taylor , " and [I]273-tinker taylor do n't doubt what [you]273-tinker taylor state . Now with [me]273-tinker taylor ' twas different . [I]273-tinker taylor always saw there was more to be learnt outside a book than in ; and [I]273-tinker taylor took [my]273-tinker taylor steps accordingly , or [I]273-tinker taylor should n't have been [the man [I]273-tinker taylor am]4967-the man i am . "[273-tinker taylor] " [You]273-tinker taylor aim at [the Church]4809-the church , [I]256-uncle joe believe ? "[256-uncle joe] said [Uncle Joe]256-uncle joe . " If [you]273-tinker taylor are such a scholar as to pitch [yer]273-tinker taylor hopes so high as that , why not give [us]4969-us a specimen of [your]273-tinker taylor scholarship ? Canst say the Creed in Latin , [man]575-man ? That was how [they]4971-they once put it to a chap down in [[my]256-uncle joe country]4972-my country . "[256-uncle joe] " [I]180-jude should think so ! "[180-jude] said [Jude]180-jude haughtily . " Not [he]1452-one of the undergraduates ! Like [his]1452-one of the undergraduates conceit ! "[1451-the ladies] screamed [one of [the ladies]1451-the ladies]1450-one of the ladies . " Just [you]273-tinker taylor shut up , [Bower o ' Bliss]4973-bower o ' bliss ! "[1452-one of the undergraduates] [He]1452-one of the undergraduates drank off the spirits in [his]1452-one of the undergraduates tumbler , rapped with it on the counter , and announced , " [The gentleman in the corner]4974-the gentleman in the corner is going to rehearse the Articles of [his]4974-the gentleman in the corner Belief , in the Latin tongue , for the edification of the company . "[1452-one of the undergraduates] " [I]180-jude wo n't ! "[180-jude] said [Jude]180-jude . " Yes - have a try ! "[1454-the surplice - maker] said [the surplice - maker]1454-the surplice - maker . " [You]273-tinker taylor ca n't ! "[256-uncle joe] said [Uncle Joe]256-uncle joe . " Yes , [he]4974-the gentleman in the corner can ! "[273-tinker taylor] said [Tinker Taylor]273-tinker taylor . " [I]180-jude 'll swear [I]180-jude can ! "[180-jude] said [Jude]180-jude . " Well , come now , stand [me]180-jude a small Scotch cold , and [I]180-jude 'll do it straight off . "[180-jude] " That 's a fair offer , "[1455-the undergraduate] said [the undergraduate]1455-the undergraduate , throwing down the money for the whisky . [The barmaid]1456-the barmaid concocted the mixture with the bearing of [a person compelled to live amongst [animals of an inferior species]1458-animals of an inferior species]1457-a person compelled to live amongst animals of an inferior species , and the glass was handed across to [Jude]180-jude , who , having drunk the contents , stood up and began rhetorically , without hesitation : " Credo in unum Deum , Patrem omnipotentem , Factorem coeli et terrae , visibilium omnium et invisibilium . "[180-jude] " Good ! Excellent Latin ! "[1448-the undergraduates] cried one of [the undergraduates]1448-the undergraduates , who , however , had not the slightest conception of a single word . A silence reigned among [the rest in [the bar]1461-the bar]1460-the rest in the bar , and [the maid]1462-the maid stood still , [Jude]180-jude 's voice echoing sonorously into [the inner parlour]1463-the inner parlour , where [the landlord]1464-the landlord was dozing , and bringing [him]1464-the landlord out to see what was going on . [Jude]180-jude had declaimed steadily ahead , and was continuing : " Crucifixus etiam pro nobis : sub Pontio Pilato passus , et sepultus est . Et resurrexit tertia die , secundum Scripturas . "[180-jude] " That 's [the Nicene]4975-the nicene , "[1465-the second undergraduate] sneered [the second undergraduate]1465-the second undergraduate . " And [we]4976-we wanted [the Apostles]4977-the apostles ' ! "[1465-the second undergraduate] " [You]180-jude did n't say so ! And [every fool]4978-every fool knows , except [you]180-jude , that the Nicene is the most historic creed ! "[1466-the auctioneer] " Let un go on , let un go on ! "[1466-the auctioneer] said [the auctioneer]1466-the auctioneer . But [Jude]180-jude 's mind seemed to grow confused soon , and [he]180-jude could not get on . [He]180-jude put [his]180-jude hand to [his]180-jude forehead , and [his]180-jude face assumed an expression of pain . " Give [him]180-jude another glass - then [he]180-jude 'll fetch up and get through it , "[273-tinker taylor] said [Tinker Taylor]273-tinker taylor . [Somebody]4067-somebody threw down threepence , the glass was handed , [Jude]180-jude stretched out [his]180-jude arm for it without looking , and having swallowed the liquor , went on in a moment in a revived voice , raising it as [he]180-jude neared the end with the manner of [a priest leading [a congregation]1469-a congregation]1468-a priest leading a congregation : " Et in Spiritum Sanctum , Dominum et vivificantem , qui ex Patre Filioque procedit . Qui cum Patre et Filio simul adoratur et conglorificatur . Qui locutus est per prophetas . "[180-jude] Et unam Catholicam et Apostolicam Ecclesiam . Confiteor unum Baptisma in remissionem peccatorum . Et exspecto Resurrectionem mortuorum . Et vitam venturi saeculi . Amen . " "[1468-a priest leading a congregation] Well done ! " said [several]1428-several , enjoying the last word , as being the first and only one [they]1428-several had recognized . Then [Jude]180-jude seemed to shake the fumes from [his]180-jude brain , as [he]180-jude stared round upon [them]1470-you . "[1470-you] [[You]1470-you pack of [fools]1472-fools]1471-you pack of fools ! " [he]180-jude cried . "[1470-you] Which one of [you]1470-you knows whether [I]0-i have said it or no ? " [The landlord]1464-the landlord , who had already had [his]1464-the landlord license endorsed for harbouring [queer characters]4981-queer characters , feared a riot , and came outside the counter ; but [Jude]180-jude , in [his]180-jude sudden flash of reason , had turned in disgust and left the scene , the door slamming with a dull thud behind [him]180-jude . [He]180-jude hastened down [the lane]493-the lane and round into [the straight broad street]4983-the straight broad street , which [he]180-jude followed till [it]4983-the straight broad street merged in [the highway]615-the highway , and all sound of [[his]180-jude late companions]4985-his late companions had been left behind . Onward [he]180-jude still went , under the influence of a childlike yearning for [the one being in the world to whom it seemed possible to fly]4986-the one being in the world to whom it seemed possible to fly - an unreasoning desire , whose ill judgement was not apparent to [him]180-jude now . In the course of an hour , when it was between ten and eleven o'clock , [he]180-jude entered [the village of Lumsdon]1272-the village of lumsdon , and reaching [the cottage]501-the cottage , saw that a light was burning in [a [downstairs room]4990-downstairs room , which [he]180-jude assumed , rightly as it happened , to be [hers]174-sue]4989-a downstairs room , which he assumed , rightly as it happened , to be hers . [Jude]180-jude stepped close to the wall , and tapped with [his]180-jude finger on the pane , saying impatiently , "[174-sue] [Sue]174-sue , [Sue]174-sue ! " [She]174-sue must have recognized [his]180-jude voice , for the light disappeared from [the apartment]4881-the apartment , and in a second or two the door was unlocked and opened , and [Sue]174-sue appeared with a candle in [her]174-sue hand . "[174-sue] Is it [Jude]180-jude ? Yes , it is ! [[My]0-i dear , [dear cousin]1478-dear cousin]1477-my dear , dear cousin , what 's the matter ? " "[0-i] Oh , [I]0-i am - [I]0-i could n't help coming , [Sue]174-sue ! " said [he]180-jude , sinking down upon the doorstep . "[174-sue] [I]0-i am so wicked , [Sue]174-sue - [my]0-i heart is nearly broken , and [I]0-i could not bear [my]0-i life as it was ! So [I]0-i have been drinking , and blaspheming , or next door to it , and saying holy things in [disreputable quarters]1479-disreputable quarters - repeating in idle bravado words which ought never to be uttered but reverently ! Oh , do anything with [me]0-i , [Sue]174-sue - kill [me]0-i - [I]0-i do n't care ! Only do n't hate [me]0-i and despise [me]0-i like [all the rest of [the world]706-the world]1480-all the rest of the world ! " "[0-i] [You]0-i are ill , [poor dear]1482-poor dear ! " With one hand holding the candle and the other supporting [him]1482-poor dear , [she]174-sue led [him]1482-poor dear indoors , and placed [him]1482-poor dear in the only easy chair [the meagrely furnished house]4992-the meagrely furnished house afforded , stretching [his]1482-poor dear feet upon another , and pulling off [his]1482-poor dear boots . [Jude]180-jude , now getting towards [his]1482-poor dear sober senses , could only say , "[795-dear] [Dear]795-dear , [dear Sue]174-sue ! " in a voice broken by grief and contrition . [She]174-sue asked [him]1482-poor dear if [he]1482-poor dear wanted anything to eat , but [he]1482-poor dear shook [his]1482-poor dear head . Then telling [him]1482-poor dear to go to sleep , and that [she]174-sue would come down early in the morning and get [him]1482-poor dear some breakfast , [she]174-sue bade [him]1482-poor dear good - night and ascended the stairs . Almost immediately [he]1482-poor dear fell into a heavy slumber , and did not wake till dawn . At first [he]1482-poor dear did not know where [he]1482-poor dear was , but by degrees [his]1482-poor dear situation cleared to [him]1482-poor dear , and [he]1482-poor dear beheld it in all the ghastliness of a right mind . [She]174-sue knew the worst of [him]1482-poor dear - the very worst . How could [he]1482-poor dear face [her]174-sue now ? [She]174-sue would soon be coming down to see about breakfast , as [she]174-sue had said , and there would [he]1482-poor dear be in all [his]1482-poor dear shame confronting [her]174-sue . [He]1482-poor dear could not bear the thought , and softly drawing on [his]1482-poor dear boots , and taking [his]1482-poor dear hat from the nail on which [she]174-sue had hung it , [he]1482-poor dear slipped noiselessly out of [the house]504-the house . [His]1482-poor dear fixed idea was to get away to some obscure spot and hide , and perhaps pray ; and the only spot which occurred to [him]1482-poor dear was [Marygreen]1-marygreen . [He]1482-poor dear called at [[his]1482-poor dear lodging in [Christminster]180-jude]4994-his lodging in christminster , where [he]1482-poor dear found awaiting [him]1482-poor dear a note of dismissal from [[his]1482-poor dear employer]4995-his employer ; and having packed up [he]1482-poor dear turned [his]1482-poor dear back upon [the city]414-the city that had been such a thorn in [his]1482-poor dear side , and struck southward into [Wessex]10-wessex . [He]1482-poor dear had no money left in [his]1482-poor dear pocket , [his]1482-poor dear small savings , deposited at [one of [the banks in [Christminster]180-jude]4998-the banks in christminster]4997-one of the banks in christminster , having fortunately been left untouched . To get to [Marygreen]1-marygreen , therefore , [his]1482-poor dear only course was walking ; and the distance being nearly twenty miles , [he]1482-poor dear had ample time to complete on the way the sobering process begun in [him]1482-poor dear . At some hour of the evening [he]1482-poor dear reached [Alfredston]20-alfredston . [Here]3898-here [he]1482-poor dear pawned [his]1482-poor dear waistcoat , and having gone out of [the town]4154-the town a mile or two , slept under a rick that night . At dawn [he]1482-poor dear rose , shook off the hayseeds and stems from [his]1482-poor dear clothes , and started again , breasting [the long white road]5001-the long white road up [the hill]564-the hill to [the downs]5003-the downs , which had been visible to [him]1482-poor dear a long way off , and passing [the milestone at the top , whereon [he]1482-poor dear had carved [his]1482-poor dear hopes years ago]5004-the milestone at the top , whereon he had carved his hopes years ago . [He]1482-poor dear reached [the ancient hamlet]5005-the ancient hamlet while [the people]5006-the people were at breakfast . Weary and mud - bespattered , but quite possessed of [his]1482-poor dear ordinary clearness of brain , [he]1482-poor dear sat down by [the well]5007-the well , thinking as [he]1482-poor dear did so what [a poor Christ]5008-a poor christ [he]1482-poor dear made . Seeing a trough of water near [he]1482-poor dear bathed [his]1482-poor dear face , and went on to [the cottage of [[his]1482-poor dear great - aunt]505-his great - aunt , whom [he]1482-poor dear found breakfasting in bed , attended by [the woman who lived with [her]505-his great - aunt]5011-the woman who lived with her]5009-the cottage of his great - aunt , whom he found breakfasting in bed , attended by the woman who lived with her . "[174-sue] What - out o ' work ? " asked [[his]1482-poor dear relative]5012-his relative , regarding [him]1482-poor dear through eyes sunken deep , under lids heavy as pot - covers , no other cause for [his]1482-poor dear tumbled appearance suggesting itself to one whose whole life had been a struggle with material things . "[174-sue] Yes , " said [Jude]180-jude heavily . "[174-sue] [I]0-i think [I]0-i must have a little rest . " Refreshed by some breakfast , [he]1482-poor dear went up to [[his]1482-poor dear old room]4433-his old room and lay down in [his]1482-poor dear shirt - sleeves , after the manner of the artizan . [He]1482-poor dear fell asleep for a short while , and when [he]1482-poor dear awoke it was as if [he]1482-poor dear had awakened in hell . It WAS hell - "[174-sue] the hell of conscious failure , " both in ambition and in love . [He]1482-poor dear thought of that previous abyss into which [he]1482-poor dear had fallen before leaving [this part of [the country]4234-the country]1206-this part of the country ; [the deepest deep [he]1482-poor dear had supposed it then]5016-the deepest deep he had supposed it then ; but it was not so deep as this . That had been the breaking in of the outer bulwarks of [his]1482-poor dear hope : this was of [his]1482-poor dear second line . If [he]1482-poor dear had been [a woman]4193-a woman [he]1482-poor dear must have screamed under the nervous tension which [he]1482-poor dear was now undergoing . But that relief being denied to [his]1482-poor dear virility , [he]1482-poor dear clenched [his]1482-poor dear teeth in misery , bringing lines about [his]1482-poor dear mouth like those in [the Laocoon]62-the laocoon , and corrugations between [his]1482-poor dear brows . A mournful wind blew through the trees , and sounded in the chimney like the pedal notes of an organ . Each ivy leaf overgrowing the wall of [the churchless church - yard]5018-the churchless church - yard hard by , now abandoned , pecked [its]5018-the churchless church - yard neighbour smartly , and the vane on [the new Victorian - Gothic church in the new spot]5019-the new victorian - gothic church in the new spot had already begun to creak . Yet apparently it was not always the outdoor wind that made the deep murmurs ; it was a voice . [He]1482-poor dear guessed its origin in a moment or two ; [the curate]5020-the curate was praying with [[his]1482-poor dear aunt]555-his aunt in [the adjoining room]5022-the adjoining room . [He]1482-poor dear remembered [her]555-his aunt speaking of [him]1482-poor dear . Presently the sounds ceased , and a step seemed to cross [the landing]5023-the landing . [Jude]180-jude sat up , and shouted "[174-sue] Hoi ! " The step made for [his]1482-poor dear door , which was open , and [a man]543-a man looked in . It was [a young clergyman]5025-a young clergyman . "[174-sue] [I]0-i think [you]1484-you are [Mr. Highridge]276-mr. highridge , " said [Jude]180-jude . "[1484-you] [[My]0-i aunt]965-my aunt has mentioned [you]1484-you more than once . Well , here [I]0-i am , just come [home]3897-home ; [a fellow gone to the bad]1487-a fellow gone to the bad ; though [I]0-i had the best intentions in [the world]706-the world at one time . Now [I]0-i am melancholy mad , what with drinking and one thing and another . " Slowly [Jude]180-jude unfolded to [the curate]5020-the curate [his]180-jude late plans and movements , by an unconscious bias dwelling less upon the intellectual and ambitious side of [his]180-jude dream , and more upon the theological , though this had , up till now , been merely a portion of the general plan of advancement . "[0-i] Now [I]0-i know [I]0-i have been [a fool]3943-a fool , and that folly is with [me]0-i , " added [Jude]180-jude in conclusion . "[3943-a fool] And [I]0-i do n't regret the collapse of [my]0-i university hopes one jot . [I]0-i would n't begin again if [I]0-i were sure to succeed . " [The curate]5020-the curate , who was [a new man]5028-a new man to [this neighbourhood]1244-this neighbourhood , had grown deeply interested , and at last [he]5020-the curate said : "[0-i] If [you]1491-you feel a real call to [the ministry]1492-the ministry , and [I]0-i wo n't say from [your]1491-you conversation that [you]1491-you do not , for it is that of [a thoughtful and educated man]1493-a thoughtful and educated man , [you]1491-you might enter [the Church]4809-the church as [a licentiate]4830-a licentiate .
